title: Excellent book
text:
Hanging Falls continues the story of Mattie Cobb. As Mattie and the team follow clues to find the killer of two people, she and Brody spend much time in the mountains with Robo. Mattie's relationship with Cole Walker continues to evolve and Mattie learns more about her past and her family.

title: The last thing she anticipated
text:
Ambitious author, Amy Mitchell’s spouse was unfaithful. The last thing she anticipated was to fall for a single dad.

Sam Whitford lost his lofty inheritance, so he moved away to the quaint village Willow Oaks. His overbearing mother visits him, and he gets the big idea to ask Amy to pretend she is his girlfriend.

Amy and Sam’s knotted endeavors and fabricated relationship muddles the truth with make-believe.

This is a tale about discovery, tolerance, taking the good with the bad, and letting love blossom in unexpected ways.

title: Split Decision
text:
The first story arc here, the Nail, ages well as one of the best works of Alan Davis. The artwork is gorgeous and the story is first rate, with lots of interesting twists and an intelligent solution (for comics). Cannot recommended it highly enough.
The second story here, Another Nail….just does not hold up. The artwork seems more rushed, and compared to the tightly plotted mystery of the original, the writing feels like a rambling mess. I was honestly bored halfway through.
A wholehearted 5 stars for The Nail, a mild “meh” with three stars for Another Nail gives us a compromise four for the combined volume, which is physically well put together.

title: Fear of being thrown away
text:
When something bad happens several times of course you will be afraid of it occurring once again. Your reactions are going to understandably be, to avoid situations that lead to that bad thing. Just because you're told by someone that you are safe doesn't mean you automatically believe their words. Especially someone like Kaden who has had his life twisted and turned so much he guards his very fragile heart. His manner of doing so is extremely frustrating to Theo the man who inherited him.

How can one's brother be such a jerk? Here Theo is searching far and wide for him, following all sorts of clues and leads, but instead of finding his brother he is handed a foul smelling box with an equally stinky and foul acting cat. What the F##k?! He risked a bunch to even go to that planet and to end up with with a frigging sticky CAT! He'd probably be laughed off the ship.

What Theo isn't aware of is that the nasty cat's really an abused Cat shifter. The shifter's plan is to get away from Theo and off the ship as soon as possible. First he has to get cleaned up, food, and a safe place to hide until he can make his escape. Cat shifters have had a terrible history and it's been in Kaden's best interest to remain a cat for many years of his life. It was often his only means of survival. Just like now.

What is Theo going to do with this irascible cat? One who destroys his room in his absence. Who is sweet as pie to everyone except him making him seem irrational. How can he deal with a feline who is as stubborn as he is? It takes calmer sensibilities to get to the heart of the matter and tell Theo what is obvious to everyone but him. Once he gets a good sniff of the cleaned up Kitty man he makes a very startling discovery...he has found his Life Mate! Now ALL he has to do is convince his skittish Cat shifter mate that they are destined to be together. Easy peasy. Riiiight!

How does he go about gaining the trust of a man who has victimized because of his small size, his cuteness, he being on his own, but mostly due to him being a Cat shifter? How can Theo get Kaden to believe his promises when Kaden has been persecuted all his life for something completely out of his control? Never having been in a loving relationship Theo bungles this one. Luckily for both he and his mate his friends and the ship's doctor is there to assist.

I didn't read the first two books in this series and I definitely felt I'd missed out on several occurrences as well as matings. It intrigued me enough to go back and read one of the previous books and continue to read future books. I enjoyed this story but I was frustrated by the lack of communication between the two MCs. I really felt sorry for the terrified little Kitty. He had such a harsh life story and he only had that as a basis of reference. I hope he finds the happiness he deserves.

title: A page-turning masterpiece due to its fun narrative voice that evoked emotion and resilience.
text:
"Well, damn," is an accurate description of this book (see blurb). Gritty, brutal, exciting, and deep, The Wizard was a page-turning masterpiece due to its fun narrative voice that evoked emotion and resilience--a light in a dark fight.

This book sucked me in from page one. Instant dragon appearance and magic, followed by political intrigue, a tad of romance, and loads of character depth? Definitely my cup of tea. I am always 100% honest in my reviews, so I devoured this book. I consumed 50% of it in a day before life's hardships interrupted my time to read. Once I was able to pick it up again, I consumed the rest, again in one sitting.

"Well, damn," is the personality of the book--yes, this book has a narrative voice full of snark and many deep emotions. So many fantasy novels these days lack that voice and focus on action and world-building, leaving us cardboard-cutout characters. This book is not that. It has a bit of everything you'd expect in fantasy but truly that voice and character depth set it apart from others. The King's Wizard, Boggs, is a man torn between his powers and morality, self-loathing for his failures and always wanting to be better. Involved with Morgan, the badass warrior princess, they team up together with others to fight a complex and interesting villain (no spoilers). The depth of the relationships and inner workings of characters' points of view is exceptional. I felt with them, rooted for them, and aligned myself with them; this narration and character depth sets aside, for me, an okay book from a great book. The Wizard is a great read.

My only issue was the improper tense shifts, but I saw no other writing issues. At times I was lost in time and not from flashbacks because those were carefully formatted differently and done well. Overall, though, if you don't teach grammar and edit on the side like I do, you probably wouldn't notice. It did not detract from the book's enjoyment at all.

Fantasy is known for its battles, and there are many inner and outer ones in this book. Descriptions of the magic and world were short and to the point, but descriptive enough to paint it alive in from of me like a movie. Perfection. The ending was phenomenal (no spoilers). I am eagerly awaiting the next book because it looks like it will be at least a trilogy.

The Wizard, by Bob Masingale, has everything one would want in a page-turning fantasy novel but its true triumph is the snarky narrative voice and world-building. "Well, damn," Bob, this book was a delight.

title: thoroughly satisfying continuation of this series, more character-driven than plot-heavy
text:
I'm rounding up just a little.

I was thrilled to learn that Bujold had written a new novella in the Sharing Knife series, and thoroughly enjoyed reading it.

I don't especially recommend this book as an entry point for the series, although Bujold does include a fair amount of background. (That background serves as a reminder for any reader who's returning to the series after long enough to need it.) For fans of the series, this is a very satisfying return to the Wide Green World and the series characters, although we spend our time only with new characters, one familiar one, and one who was only glimpsed. (We do get to hear how some events set in motion in the earlier books have progressed.)

It's good to see how much the familiar character, Barr, has grown since our first introduction to him and our last view of him. The book shows some of that growth in progress, or perhaps Barr's growing understanding of it.

There's suspense both personal and otherwise, but this is not one of the more plot-heavy books in the series.

title: Delightful!
text:
Although the writing was simplistic the story was different from your typical love story. A very sweet tale that made me want to not only want to finish reading but to buy the sequel as well.

After writing my initial review I read some of the others. I found it interesting that so many negative expressions of unrealistic behavior are voiced about how the relationship begins. Is Chris's situation that different from mail order brides or arranged marraiges of the past? Is it really unbelievable that someone who was spending a lot of money to reach a goal wouldn't use whatever tools were available to increase the odds of a positive result? Just because will inhibiting or mind altering substances are frowned on in this culture that doesn't mean that someone from another world would have a problem using them. Why is it so unbelievable that Caitlyn wouldn't be able to adjust to her new life after experiencing such a substance? I still enjoyed the premise if the tale. I especially enjoyed the way the two aliens were so different in their thought processes. People from the same place can see things very differently and won't respond the same way to stimuli.

I stand by my rating. Chris wanted to be a partner with his mate not dominate and rule everything. He focused on learning about his mate in particular while his friend had a different approach to reaching a similar goal and focused on learning how this world works. It was exactly like the difference between the way a single person views life differently than a married person.

title: It's a wet dream
text: This book is a wet dream.  It is a beautifully written wet dream... but still a wet dream.  It is a boy's fantasy.  The boy dreams that he can rape the woman he desires, the woman who doesn't desire him, and somehow it will all be OK.  Somehow she will not only forgive him but will fall in love with him and then they will manage to live, not just happily ever after, but they will somehow have a sexually fulfilled future.  The women aren't cheeseburgers.  The characters are rounded.  But, still, it is a wet dream.  Women don't fall in love with their rapists.  Women have 8 to 12 years of nightmares after rape.  Rape is not OK and women will not have a mutually supportive relationship with theirrapist.

title: Beautiful
text:
I was so excited to see Instructions for Dancing by Nicola Yoon as one of Book of the Month's June picks! It was one of my most anticipated books for 2021, so I added it instantly, and it didn’t disappoint! ⁣
⁣
I really liked Evie. Her reasons for her cynicism and distrust for love, especially as a teenager, made so much sense to me and were even relatable to an extent. I loved her friends and how different they all were from one another but fit together so well. Then of course there is X. He’s so different from Evie, with his belief in only saying yes, and they work. They make sense, and I loved them together. Add in the hilarious dance instructor, Fifi and you have a mix of characters. ⁣
⁣
Nicola Yoon is funny. She has a way of describing things with sarcasm that really resonates with me, but she is also great at adding depth to a book and she certainly made me cry with this one. I’ve mentioned a thousand times that I am a fan of a romance that isn’t 100% happy and she delivered for me.⁣
⁣
I loved the magical realism in this, and I like that it wasn’t explained what it was, how it worked, or really even why it was there. I don’t need that. I knew there was going to be some magic going in and that was good enough for me, but I do know some people will have an issue with that. I did feel the ending was a bit abrupt, but it wasn’t bad. It just felt quick. ⁣
⁣
Overall this was a complete win for me. I need to read Everything, Everything and in the future, I know Nicola Yoon will be an auto-buy author for me!

title: Holy Hot Biker Bad Boy!
text:
Holy Hot Biker Bad Boy!

First of all, loved it. I tore through this book. The story was gripping, it was so well-written and I MUST go back and read Grit (although THIS IS A STANDALONE, I enjoyed it SO much that I want to read more about the Spartans MC!)

I love how the introduction and and interaction between Talia and Tucker was there right out of the gate, that I didn't have to read half of the book before they met. And what an introduction and interaction it was!

Early on, I learned that Talia is guarding a HUGE secret (no spoilers!) and I COULD NOT WAIT to see what happened once it came to light. And, boy, did it! I loved her spunk and her faults, and her relentlessness.

Tucker was AMAZING. I loved how he treated Talia differently from the start, even though he didn't know why he was doing it. His vulnerability, though well hidden, made him just adorable (in an ex-Special Ops, total badass sort of way).

All in all, I LOVED it and can't wait to read more about these sexy Spartans!!!

***I received a copy of this book in exchange for an honest review***

title: Pride and Prejudice completely redone!
text:
This is the best variation out so far! Everything is so unexpected! Nothing follows the original book except the personalities of our favorite characters.

When Elizabeth meets Darcy at the Meryton assembly, she also has the opportunity to meet his cousin, Colonel Fitzwilliam. Her impression of Darcy is the same as canon; proud and above his company. She hears his opinion of her, but the colonel asks to be introduced to assuage any hurt feelings. They have a lovely time together talking before he must return to the front, he'd been recuperating from a leg wound.

When they meet again in Kent, the colonel is now the viscount as his older brother has died. Her opinion of him before had been good but they had both been too poor to consider a union. Now his prospects are great and the lady who was interesting and interested in his person, not his money or title, may make a wonderful wife.

How this upsets Darcy and what he does to handle it is well worth the reading and rereading. This edited review comes after the third perusal.

title: You can't go wrong witha Dee Henderson novel
text:
Dee Henderson is a master story teller. No, make that Master Story Creator and Teller. Her stories always suck me in and have me reluctant to put the book down, even at 4 am. Unspoken continues her legacy of great reads full of romance, suspense and faith.

Faith is a topic that is always very strong in Dee's books, but maybe not in the traditional way some come to expect from Christian novels. It's not all about non-believer meets believer and a soul is saved, although there's certainly nothing wrong with that. I love those tales too. But what I appreciate about Dee's books, is that whether the character is a believer or not, or maybe just questioning - it's about the personal journey. You see inside their hearts and minds, you know them deep inside and understand their struggles with life. You understand how they can believe so strongly despite a horrid past event or maybe how that past event could be hindering their growth. Either way, it's insight. That insight makes you connect to the story on a deeper level and you can't help but feel the tension, romance, suspense and frustration stronger when you're connected at that level to the character. I also appreciate that with each story there is spiritual growth in some measure and I know I can't help but carry that with me to think on later when the story is done.

So how can I not love a Dee Henderson novel? Unspoken has all the above - and I get a great romantic suspense with a good looking guy that makes my heart want to pitter-patter a little harder when he walks onto the page.

You can't go wrong with a Dee Henderson book. You just can't.

I received a free copy of this book from the publisher to review.

title: I love Bliss Devlin’s Children of Lilith series although I haven’t ...
text:
I received a complimentary copy in exchange for an honest review.

I love Bliss Devlin’s Children of Lilith series although I haven’t read it in what seems like forever. Her Incubus Master was the perfect reintroduction. I would also like to say this was my first ever audiobook, and I was pleasantly surprised. At first, it was a bit weird. I am not much for dirty talk, so hearing this mature voiced gentleman saying such scandalous things almost stopped my heart! I made the mistake of listening to it while I was driving and had to stop before I wrecked my car! Not seriously, but I dare you to listen to this without being affected.

In this story, Devlin brings her expertise in BDSM to her skillful storytelling. Andras is not only a skilled Master, but a considerate one as well. While I felt that Katie didn’t particularly stand out as far as heroines go, I was envious of her. Their relationship felt real and heartfelt, regardless of what they were doing.

There are a lot of BDSM erotica out there, but Devlin’s Children of Lilith is among the best, especially if you like a little fantasy and magic to go along with it.

title: Good not great

title: They met by chance but, will love give them a second chance ?
text: Chance and Aubrey met at a rest stop in Nebraska. Who know how their life would end up. It was fate that his motorcycle wouldn't start and she had a flat tire. Spending a little over a week together brought them so close until Chance snuck out anyone morning. Aubrey was devastated and had no idea where he disappeared or why. 2 years later she finds out and Chance tries just about everything to win her back.

title: A great Story
text:
The story follows Jack who is embarking on a major project, trying to get it back on track but as he is chilling before the big push begins he sees a woman who produces feelings he has not felt before.

Gillian is at the stupid BBQ at the request of her father but is not enjoying it, she has spotted the handsome man standing all night by the tree in the backyard, when he gets the courage to speak to her and then asks to dance with her the chemistry between them is off the charts until she receives a phone call which she has to take and go home.

Jack is gutted that this beautiful woman has escaped and he did not even get any detail from her, but he is only in the town for a few weeks that he is disappointed but life carries on. When he arrives at the big green project it all becomes clear and with having to deal with a mystery thief can this job get any harder and then in walks JT Vickers.

I loved this story, it was sweet and although the character of Jack was alpha male esk, Gilly gave as good to him. The other characters really made the story and for the mystery thief that was brilliant. This is the first book I have read by this author and enjoyed every word, the story flowed along and I read this within one sitting. The story can be read as a standalone book but can't wait to download the rest of the series.

title: Okay but also kind of disappointing because of Caspion :P
text:
2.5-3 stars

***Spoiler warning!!! I go into some details in this review so please don't read if you want to avoid spoilers***

This story was rather disappointing... I will admit that I already had issues with Caspion's behavior in Shadow's Claim. He seemed selfish and immature and I didn't like how he treated Bettina at all. I was hoping that he'd be better in this book but TBH, Caspion pretty much ruined any possibility that this book could get a higher rating from me. I seriously did consider giving it a lower rating but the story itself and the other characters don't deserve that...just Caspion.

So, those that have read the previous book (Shadow's Claim) know that Caspion is a tracker that was friends with Bettina and ended up entering the competition for her hand in marriage (in Shadow's Claim) to avoid a death he was marked for because he left the land of Dacia (which is forbidden). This story takes place both before and after that event.

Basically, Caspion is screwing around at an orgy when he catches the eye of Mirceo, who is a vampire and the Prince of Dacia. Mirceo invites him over and he declines but Mirceo persists. Caspion indicates he's straight and he and Mirceo become best buddies and spend a few weeks or so together, visiting all the brothels and orgies they can. They feel a strong connection and so obviously, Mirceo says "It must be because you're destined for my sister. Come to Dacia to meet her but be warned, once you enter our land, you can't leave or you'll be killed" (paraphrased but that's basically it). Caspion decides his instincts are telling him to go to Dacia so he does...only to find that Mirceo's sister isn't his mate after all. Something intimate happens between Caspion and Mirceo and Caspion ;eaves Dacia and goes running home with death on his heals and that's where Shadow's Claim comes in.

After his defeat in the competition, Caspion can't deal and so he goes off to a demon realm where time works differently to gain strength and money. A week or so in our time is 500 years or so in that realm so Caspion comes back much stronger and more confident than he was before. Mirceo had actually been trying to find him before he left for the other realm and instead, found him after he had come back. While they were apart, Mirceo had lost his heartbeat and suspected that Caspion was his mate and indeed, Mirceo was "blooded" (regained his heartbeat) when he got near Caspion, proving Caspion is his mate.

This starts a long line of denial, denial, denial. Caspion basically used every reason he could think of as to why they couldn't be mates, most of which were completely unfair. Also, since Caspion was technically much older than Mirceo after his time in the other realm, he seemed to feel the need to treat Mirceo like a child or something. He kept calling Mirceo names like Leechling, which seemed not only demeaning but also condescending. Also, Caspion couldn't seem to decide whether Mirceo was his BFF or a hated enemy...it seemed to vary by mood.

I'm not saying Mirceo was perfect, he made his mistakes and some were doozies. However, Caspion made a ton of assumptions about Mirceo and they were just a bunch of crap and it made it very difficult for Mirceo to even begin to prove himself to Caspion. Caspion tried to say that he knew Mirceo better than he knew himself when Caspion only really know him while they were partying together for a while and he saw that as the sum total of Mirceo and nothing else mattered to him.

Sorry I got a little carried away with my annoyance about Caspion but he just realy bothered me... Thankfully, this crap did get settled (but not until the very end) and Mirceo and Caspion end up together and heading towards a HEA (although the story does end with a cliffy concerning Mirceo's sister).

title: So Real
text:
Reading this series has been one of the best decisions I've made. I have enjoyed every book and Legacy has blown me away. This book seemed so realistic, with real people and real life problems. No cheesy outlandish problem solving. Every issue was handled the way that real life goes, good or bad. Real life throws things at you rather you are ready for it or not and you can't go back and change the decision you made at that time because you've already set off the chain of events. Legacy is a perfect example of that.
I smiled, I cried, and then I smiled through my tears....

title: Enjoyable Read
text: I came across this selection by accident through Amazon's free kindle books available and I enjoyed it so much that I had to complete the series with books #2 and #3 immediately after.  The Lunarmorte series is, as I understand it, this author's first attempt at writing and she did a fantastic job.  I fell in love with the characters and their struggles and found myself dying to see the story through.  It is a fantasy story, so expect some parts to be a bit over the top in the fantasy realm and the main character is a bit ... "fantastical".  With that being said, I enjoyed the way that Young adds the romance and bonding aspect without being too vulgar, repeatedly brings the characters back to earth with more humble, human qualities and wraps it up in an enjoyable mixture of action and suspense.  I highly recommend this book to anyone that enjoys stories about the supernatural realm of werewolves, vampires and fairies, but doesn't want the in-your-face sexual encounters of a "Sookie Stackhouse" novel.  I recommend it for adults and older teens keeping in mind that there are sexual situations and violence that may not be appropriate for the younger groups and I would say that it is very comparable to the "House of Night" series.  I gave it a five star rating, not based on the complexity or other technical critiques, but based on how much I enjoyed reading it.  If you enjoy losing yourself to another world for a while, I completely recommend losing yourself with Caia and friends in the Lunarmorte series.

title: The fictional life of a wild mink aimed at a young adult audience
text: I love this mink.  It tells the life of a young mink, Vison in the wild, his development into an adult and his eventual end as an old, rugged mink.  The author is a naturalist and the story is about 50 years old and aimed at the young adult audience. It also tells the life of men living along the Potomic River and their interactions with this mink and his uncanny ability to avoid traps.  Vison is a clever mink and reluctantly respected by the river men.  Times have changed in the last 50 years and attitudes about hunting and trapping have changed with them.

title: Great Story!
text:
4 – 4.5 Stars

I am really enjoying this series so far and I loved Ash and Isaiah’s story! These two men share a rough, career ending history but when they are reunited at the bachelor auction, it’s all about the future for them.

Immediately, I liked both Ash and Isaiah and really did feel for the things they’d gone through. Ten years after their incident they are now both successful men, Isaiah has come to terms with the man he is and is out and proud, while Ash, well he’s certainly successful and kind and does so much good but can’t forgive himself for the mistake he made. They share a great connection but Ash fights it, struggling with his guilt and afraid of damaging Isaiah’s reputation. I loved how honest and real Isaiah was about his feelings for Ash and their situation.

I thought this this was a great mix of steamy romance, a bit of angst and some heart-melting forgiveness and love! I definitely enjoyed this book from start to finish, I didn’t want to put it down! A great addition to this series and I’m really looking forward to continuing on with this group!

title: Rand's Pernicious Nonsense (makes a try) in "Continuance";
text:
Those seeking a genuine appraisal of the "works" of Ayn Rand, may like to look over this offering - revealing nothing new and thereby everything about itself - at the same time. Although similarly sickeningly and one-eyed beyond reason as is the rest of the "collection" to a functioning mind, it starts to become too evident for even her supporters to pretend to ignore the fact that there WAS no new information coming from the "House of Rand" - because none existed. Far from being groundbreaking (unless you're talking digging up corpses), it was old before it got "reworked" for the first let alone the 457th incarnation of the same old idle repetitions.

In between yet another endless quoting and re-quoting of herself, and her earlier rather horrendously skewed "texts" she misnomered to be "For the (New) Intellectual" among other treasonous covers, Rand/Rosenbaum continues on her hellbent course to tell all ('mankind', or 'men qua men'?) already browbeaten into further hearing her, even then as if from "beyond the grave", that she understood how a process of "automatizing" (or "automization") in her sublanguage could stand-in for a natural and able cognitive development.

Far from describing growth in real human terms, it is precisely that which "Rand" sought to overtake and supplant with an overcalling sub-variety of unoriginal and reductionist terms that would render the human mind as if prefigured by some form of faked and non-functional (anti-any and all sort of) "nano-technology". Primitively so. Cloning as it "goes". Always as if "speaking" from before the event, as if pre-cognitively, while claiming to be against that - and just about everything else, excepting, (prater) naturally, ONLY and however "strictly" - itself.

The "Rand" ploy in a nutshell. Try to falsely divide and accuse part of your 'audience' (which you don't bother to visualize but in a dull and warping mirror) of that which you are 'yourself'. Then restate it another several hundred times, in as many variations as you can mock up, all amounting to the same 'nothing' that 'you' overcall as everything else - and (as if pretending to be over) everyone else. Nothing more than a badly fractured and imploded dead-ended remains of what once may have had the chance to be an intellect if not so badly gutted and inverted by its own hand. Pretending blindness and omniscience in the same notional fell (and foul) swoop.

It's the worst kind of pretender and fake valuer that must be against (its own job lot of a) "something" to be anything at all. It claims a false type of ultra fanatical and farcical "positivism" which is negated by its "own" stance. It then engages in a further pretense (and twist) to label that which it "identifies" by its own thoroughly irrational and absurd "standard" as "an" "other" that it pretends to defeat over and over again. In one vital sense, it does. In entirely self-defeatest terms pretending by a game of false opposites to lay a claim to the entire field of human cognition. Yet another "divide" and try "rule", strategist, this "one" all the more foul for attempting to hide it from 'herself'. Furthermore, for trying to use the human race as fodder to do it. Moreover, those in an otherwise free world, to whatever degree beyond her canting that tries reduce the entire sum to a false equation by means of an equally false elevation of a minor few. Even the language of the offering above continues in this same (old) vein (which could better be spelled 'VAIN'), using such immortal words as the "all too few heroically minded" to 'amp up' her none-too-few followers with a prosaic kind of "lift". Too bad by the time many of them could have realized it was as if a shove of the head under, many have given up the ability to 'see' anything except through her sadly demented eyes, and split "vision" accordingly.

Utterly foul stuff and perhaps the greatest fake - and mass of self-delusion and false self projection I've had the misfortune to come across.

It is true that "Rand" did attempt to "suck up" (there are no other words to describe her maneuver to try an "appeal") to individual and genuinely independent minds, and human values with the same blow on the side of the head as just now outlined and as only she best 'described' it. The "collection" "repurposed" so as to be on offer above to those of her converted persuasion has since (and already manifestly) revealed itself as an all too apparent truly PRIMITIVE subset of its own disturbed kind of whack - literally - that is the only "thing" "Rand" truly "knew" anything about.

No matter how she (or her latter-day mouthpieces) try to re-doctor her tired out, old and failed expressions, they still have yet to produce anything original - or anything at all that's not defined as idle and empty repetition and regurgitation. That's about (and rather exactly) all it's good for. Proof positive, in this "volume" offered above, and many others almost identical in form, content, expression and "integrating" power. A zilch, which is to say, yet another notional vacuum.

Only best left un-stomached, as all it does is upset the digestion.

title: Wonderful inspirational story
text:
Alexa Verde’s book Show Me The Boss:

When Kansas decides to take Nehemiah on a vacation to his friend Kimberly’s ranch his life will change. Liberty is a amazing woman who loves her family and her job. When Kansas shows up Liberty isn’t happy. Watching these two work through their differences will have you on the edge of your seat. This book is truly inspirational and impossible to stop reading it. You will feel God working throughout this wonderful story. I had the honor to review this book for the author for a honest review. I would give this book a higher rating than a five star review if I could.

title: Interstellar mercenaries doing what they do best - fight!
text:
The legion continues its fighting retreat in the Median Empire. The pacing was quite good involving a series of battles without getting sensory overload. Xenephron is developing into a good strategist and as a fighter. Five stars was given because this book can be re-read several times.

What might throw a new reader off is the organization structure of the legion which is based on the city states structure of Ancient Greece. Humanity has grown into separate systems and culture. Collectively the humans are a formidable fighting force when working together, but they have a tendency to compete and fight amongst themselves. Thomas has given a good blend of sci-fi fighting using projectile weapons and laser along with swords for close combat.

The strategy is comparable to the character of Cletus from Gordon Dicksons Dorsai series.

title: Disney movies were always an inspirational part of my childhood ...
text: Disney movies were always an inspirational part of my childhood, especially when I live in the same state as Walt Disney Studios. I know a lot of people who grew up with Disney movies and I know some who work for Disney and in collaboration with Disney to make movies today. This book tells all about how Walt got Disney started and the events in his life before Disney had even come around. Learning the life and history of classics helps to give  you a broader perspective on how things have flourished since creation.

title: Imaginative premise!
text:
I enjoyed this one. The description of this book really appealed to me from the start so I thought it would be worth a try. I was really curious about how the ability to see when your relationship with someone would end would play out in a story, and I think that it worked pretty well. This was a really quick read, and I found it to be quite enjoyable.

When Quinn touches someone for the first time, she sees how that relationship will end. She knows if it will be a long term relationship or if it will end quickly. I thought that this was a really interesting ability and it made sense that it would have a big impact on Quinn's life. Do you go out on a date with someone you know will break your heart? Unfortunately, even though she knows what is going to happen, she can't do anything to stop it.

Quinn meets Griffin at an art gallery. They are both there to find inspiration: Quinn for her photography and Griffin for his music. When she touches him, she sees that he will die soon while telling her that he loves her. As fate would have it, she soon learns that he lives in the same apartment complex as she lives with her grandmother. They are drawn to each other and love spending time with each other but Quinn is afraid that she might be the cause of his upcoming death.

I liked the characters in this book. Quinn had been through a lot in her life and her special abilities have not made things any easier for her. Griffin has had his own challenges and is trying to start fresh on his own in a different state. It really seemed like these two needed each other and I thought that they were good together. Quinn's friend Olivia was a good source of support for her and her new boyfriend, Jack, seemed like a good guy as well.

I do wish that we would have had the chance to see Quinn have to deal with her powers more often in this book. I only remember it happening twice in the story and I think it would have made the story more interesting if it came up more often. I didn't find the mystery to be too hard to figure out but I was still eager to see how things played out. There were a couple of times in the story when things felt a little too convenient but nothing that I couldn't look past.

I would recommend this book to others. I thought that this was a fun story with an imaginative premise. I wouldn't hesitate to read more of this author's work in the future.

I received a digital review copy of this book from Entangled: Teen via NetGalley.

title: I wanted to like this so much I preordered it but it was bad
text:
I LOVE the ACOTAR trilogy. I reread it at least 1-2x/ year. And, as much as I loved the trilogy, I hated the novella aka "ACOTAR a Christmas Special." The novella took a character I found interesting and broke her and made her near irredeemable. I still preordered this book tho, in the hopes that I could forget the novella existed and really enjoy this s one. I was SORELY disappointed.

*****SPOILERS*****

The first 75% of this book was a slog fest. I picked it up and out it down over a dozen times. All of the things I loved about the earlier books-- fleshed out side characters, Cassian as a capable General, the rich world lore-- was just...absent. The only spot of interest in this section is the visit to the bog. Outside of that the action falls into two categories: Nesta's anger at herself & everyone else, and exotic sex with Cassian. When I say erotic, I mean erotic. I'm not exaggerating. We are treated to the location of someone's bodily fluids in nearly every sex scene, of which there are dozens. And, because so much space is spent on sex and internal conflict there is too little space given to nearly everything else. For example, Nesta makes 2 friends and other than their names and homes we learn nothing else about them until the Blood Rite in the last 25% of the book. Nothing new happens with any of the side characters Amen, Vassa, Lucien, Elaine, Ariel, Mor, Eric, Tamlin or Koschei. There is some vague stuff regarding each of them but nothing to hook readers for more like in the trilogy.

And there is a subplot I need to rant about because it's SO stupid. After the novella we all know that Feyre's pregnant. The subplot involves Feyre's and the baby's lives being in danger bc the baby has wings and thus Rhys's life being in danger bc of his bargain with Feyre to die when she dies. Feyre is a SHAPESHIFTER. Also she's MATED to Rhys. BOTH of these things make this subplot beyond stupid. If it's dangerous to give birth Feyre would not be his mate. Which, is also true for Cassian and Nesta. Matehood is supposed to help ensure genetically better offspring, which is impossible if mother and child die from the process. Also, Feyre is a SHAPESHIFTER. It's what she is, amongst other things. What good is her power if she can't use it. So dumb. And because it's so dumb it robs Nesta's sacrifice to save them of most of its meaning.

Which brings me to the last 25% of the book. It was great. I couldn't out it down. Right up until Nesta traded her powers away to save two people who only needed saving because the subplot was ridiculous. In the original trilogy every subplot added something. In this book it managed to take away from one of just 3 times when Nesta purposefully
flexed her powers. Btw, we are never told the full extent of powers and then they are gone.

Finally, as a whole, I disliked the plot and what it did to the main characters. Cassian and Nesta lost their identities and became Rhys-and-Feyre-lite but with kinkier sex.

In sum, nearly everything about this book was worse than the novella. Not even in the same stratosphere as books 1-3. There was so much potential from the trilogy and the space of a full-length novel and what was produced felt like someone else, less experienced, wrote it. I don't understand the high reviews. It really feels like the author was done after book 3 and was forced to keep writing. There's no heart in it anymore.

Hence, 1 star.

title: Get ready to laugh!
text:
Welcome back to Tickled Pink, where you are going to laugh and fall in love with this world and characters. Pippa Grant writes stories you can connect with, places you want to move to and just belong, and this book is a perfect example of that.

We met Tavi in “The one Who Loves You” and we just got a taste of her quirky almost bipolar personality. Tavi is an influencer that has dreams for so much more, but like the rest of the Lightly’s she is commanded by her grandmother to drop everything and move to Tickled Pink.

Once again Pippa has given us a book about self awareness and the want and need to do better, to do better for themselves as well as the others around them. This is the second book in this series and it is definitely worth the read, it can be read as a stand-alone but I don’t know why you wouldn’t want to spend time with these characters!

title: Well Drawn Characters
text:
This is a familiar theme in which two super-successful entertainers, Audrey and Harlow, meet and fall in love. Of course, their careers get in the way of having a “normal” relationship, but they are committed to making the relationship work. However, the relationship cannot withstand Harlow’s brother’s betrayals.

The characters in this book are well drawn and likable, but the book is seriously flawed by the author’s plotting skills. There are at least two improbable results of Harlow’s brother’s perfidy, i.e., major breakthroughs after two weeks of therapy and forgiveness too easily and too soon given. Then there are the pages and pages of the author telling us what the characters are thinking/feeling – undoubtedly readers will find themselves zoning out and skimming along until the characters reappear.

While this isn’t the best book in LesFic for 2021, but isn’t the worse book, not by a long shot.

My thanks to Bold Strokes Books for an eARC.

title: Deja Vu All Over Again
text:
I've never read anything by Stephen Ambrose until now, but with his reputation was eager to read this account of building the transcontinental railroad. He packs the pages with extensive background facts, ties it to other history of the time, and then to make sure you don't forget them, repeats them countless times, chapter after chapter, except typically with nuances of difference. The end result is you're never really sure what's accurate. Just like the saying "a man with one watch knows what time it is; a man with two is never really sure."

Truth is, I discounted other reviewer comments here based on Ambrose's notoriety. But the reality is after slogging through 12 chapters, I'll keep going for the six more to complete the story.

That said, here's the real takeaway. The book has 17 chapters and an epilogue. Each of them have multiple sections. Each section seems to be written as a standalone account of some aspect of building the transcontinental railroad. But(!!!)...nobody, no editor, no publisher, not even the writer himself does much to give them the luxury of any continuity of flow nor do anything to cross out factoids already said many times over. Say it once or twice and I'll probably remember it. Say it five or ten times...odds are I'm confused with a frequent sense of deja vu. Frankly that's both irritating and insulting. And it's a shame, because he has a great deal of facts and interesting side stories. But organization of the manuscript is sadly lacking. With just a little of that organization and editing, this would otherwise have been a great book.

But, like I said, I'll go ahead and finish it.

title: Quick novella with a swoon worthy hero, a tight nit group of friends
text:
Review on behalf of The Book Boyfriend Addict

When We Become One is the third book in The Richmond Series where Rae Daniel has created a group of friends that genuinely care about each other. Although each one is a novella you are still able to experience the bonds these characters have created. This story starts with Marisa aka Ris who is in a relationship with Trent that is nothing more than comfortable. She knows they lack spark but has convinced herself that maybe that’s how it is supposed to be.

Before long Ris finds out that Trent is not who the man she thought he was and thankfully gets out of the relationship. In comes David a strong, loving and compassionate man that is ready to sweep Ris off her feet. However, Ris has a past she needs to get over before she can even consider a possibility with someone else. While things start to heat up between David and Ris so does the suspense and danger.

"...Now, I know we've not know each other very long, but I feel a connections with you, I can't explain it . I feel like being with you is right. I can't seem to stay away."

David does everything he can to find out who is sabotaging his company and at the same time trying to protect Ris from the past that is coming back to haunt her. David is a swoon worthy hero saying all the right things at the right time. Although there is insta-love the characters recognize that there is just something electric between them that it is worth fighting.

"Damn, David, how the f*@# are you not married? That was some serious crazy and alpha make stuff right there."

If you’re looking for a quick novella with a swoon worthy hero, a tight nit group of friends along with some danger thrown in than When We Become One is the book for you. You can pick up right at book three and not be lost however the first two in the series are free on KU and are also quick reads if you want to catch up.

Complementary copy provided by the author for an honest review.

title: 💖💖💖 4.5 Sweet & Sexy Stars 💖💖💖
text:
I went into A HIGHLANDER WALKS INTO A BAR with only a few things in mind...it's by Laura Trentham, an author that I've read and enjoyed before, it's a small town romance, of which I'm a fan, and, it's set in the South, a win for me (note the blog name... 😘 ). I could not be happier with this book, which left me smiling from start to finish and laughing out loud on more than one occasion.

As hard as she tries not to be, Isabel is wide open, a creative soul intent on hiding her light under a bushel. It takes a very sexy Scot on a mission to retrieve his erstwhile uncle to open her eyes and give her the push she needs to embrace the things that really make her heart sing. Turnabout is only fair, because spending time with Isabel in the very special town of Highland, GA, opens Alasdair's eyes to the really important things in life. The romance is sweet and sexy, a little bit steamy, but just the right amount for Izzy and Alasdair, and there is plenty of humor, which makes for a nice balance and a really entertaining and heartwarming read.

Quirky supporting characters, including Isabel's mother and Alasdair's uncle, make the road to their enlightenment all the more delightful, and help create a very special place that I'm looking forward to visiting again. Which is great, because there is more Highland to come, and I can't wait. 💖

title: Really impressed by this character-driven mystery novel
text:
It's just another day in Mount Oanoke, Pennsylvania when the birds start to fall. Hundreds of dead starlings, dropping from the sky during a baseball game. It seems like the birds started it all, but really the secrets and lies began much earlier. Nate Winters, high school teacher and baseball coach, is beloved in the town. That is, until a reporter, in town to cover the birds, catches Nate hugging a student at a local motel. Suddenly, the birds are forgotten, and the story becomes much juicier: Nate; his student, Lucia; and their supposed affair. Lucia fuels the fire by affirming the affair and suddenly Nate and his wife, Alecia, are swept up in the story. The only who believes in Nate's innocence, even a sliver, is his friend and co-worker, Bridget. As Lucia's creative writing teacher, she has unique insight into the girl's mind. But when Lucia suddenly goes missing--with Nate as the prime suspect in her disappearance--not even Bridget may be able to save Nate. But is there more to Lucia's disappearance than an affair with her teacher?

Wow, I was really impressed by this novel. It's a complicated novel that is just as much a character-driven study as it is a mystery. It's incredibly well-written, and Moretti expertly embodies the voice of each of her characters, from beleaguered Alecia, who is worn down from mothering her autistic son, Gabe; to the cast of teenager characters; to Bridget, who lost her husband to cancer a year ago. It's so well-done that often with each chapter (which skip from various points of view -- Bridget, Kate, Lucia, Nate, etc.), I found my myself veering between whom I preferred or believed, constantly second-guessing my allegiances or what happened. This is very rare for me: typically I find my "person" in a novel and stick with them, no matter what.

But here, I was confused, wondering. Was Nate really a cad, who cheated on his wife every second he got, or was he the sweet, affable teacher and baseball coach that the whole town admired and adored? And Alecia--was she more than just a weary mom, broken down by years of staying at home with her autistic son, Gabe, unable to give to anyone beyond him? Did she push Nate away, into the arms of others? Or was the truth more complicated that all of this? I have to hand it to Moretti--she was excellent at creating confusion and doubt. In addition to different perspectives, the novel shifts in time (before the birds fell, after the birds fell, before Lucia disappeared, etc.). It's a little tough to keep track of, but it also keeps you on your toes and always wondering, as you piece various parts of the puzzle together.

For me--even more than the mystery of what exactly happened with Lucia--the strength of this novel was the writing and the characters. I felt for them, even when I was frustrated with them. Moretti captures the angst and meanness of high school extremely well, portraying the cliques of a small town quite superbly. (I was reminded of WHEN WE WERE WORTHY, which I just finished.) I loved the juxtaposition of this being a small town, so the idea is that everyone knows everyone and everything, and yet there are so many secrets, so much unknown. Being a witness to Alecia and Nate's marriage is amazing-- you see firsthand how the events affect them and how they've reached this point. It's an incredibly realistic portrayal of marriage and of motherhood.

As you probably tell, I just really liked this novel. It's very well-written, with quite compelling characters. I worked out some of the plot, but it didn't stop me from reading at all. I think some of the emphasis on character development slows the story at places, but not in any detrimental way. This one will make you think, as well as intrigue you with what happened to Lucia. Quite worth the read.

I received a copy of this novel from the publisher and Netgalley (thank you!) in return for an unbiased review.

title: Sullivan Island, great summer read.
text: Dorothea Benton Frank is my go-to-author for a nice summer read.  Her books take place in Charleston, SC for the most part and this is an area I know fairly well.  Every story she writes has good characters, strong families and happy endings.  This particular book was the author's first book.  I had read other of her books and decided to start at the beginning.  The main character is Susan who unexpectedly finds herself divorced, a single mother.  The story moves back and forth between 1960's and past times, focusing on her dysfunctional childhood and changes forced upon her as an adult.  There is humor and hope and everyone needs a Sullivan Island in their lives.

title: Great recipes, rather heavy-handed with the "rah, rah - go vegan!" pitch
text: This book feels like more of a how-to guide to becoming a vegan, complete with a litany of health, environmental, ethical, and lifestyle benefits, than it does a cookbook. As someone who has decided to go vegan, I think there are some great tips such as start slowly and concentrate on making sure I get enough protein. On the other hand, I'm still upset at the suggestion that if I ever question my resolve I should go visit a petting zoo for a reminder. Really? That's not necessary. The book is informative, well-written and easy to understand, and therefore appropriately targeted toward beginners. However, far too many pages are focused on the decision to go vegan. I'm already there and I wanted some great, simple recipes. True, the recipes look delicious but I could have lived without what felt like a  preacher's sermon on the benefits of veganism. I now feel like there's something wrong with me if I can't stick with it. Like I said, though, the recipes look worth it and you can skip the pages that seem like a sales pitch, if you want.

I would find myself failing to remember the gender the character was "supposed" to be and distracted figuring out  who these characters would be in the original book. So, this reading was a bit strange. However, I appreciate Meyer's meticulous detail for editing and all of the tweaks that improved the dialogue made this story great. I was wondering how she would keep this story going with obvious future plot twists being gender specific. She surprised me with an alternate ending that wrapped it up nicely if not perfectly happily ever after : )

It's filled with oddly advanced technology for 1900s New York, but that could be because of the octopus people who are the children of ancient Gods mingling with human society. You have to suspend a great deal of disbelieve here, but isn't that the point of fantasy? Just relax and enjoy the ride. The only thing keeping me from giving this 5 stars is the sheer amount of literal Dues Ex Machina. But this is a fast enjoyable read I recommend for anyone that needs an escape.

title: Another fabulous collection of personal essays from the Counter-Culture Diva!
text:
If you enjoyed The Counter-Culture Diva's first book, "My Life, A Four Letter Word," you will love her latest collection of funny, poignant personal essays. With sweet naivete, brutal honesty, and humorous punch, Dolores takes us through the various odd jobs and wacky experiences she had while navigating the tricky profession of show business. From a nude bubble wrap stint on the $1.98 Beauty Show to trimming a porn star's pubic hair, is seems like there is very little Dolores HASN'T done!! Her "Tell Mama" one-woman service company took her to some odd places and encounters with a cast of unsavory and delightfully strange people.

But don't let the humor fool you -- Dolores doesn't shy away from exposing the more painful, emotional aspects of her life. As a single mother raising a young girl, without a steady job, Dolores was often caught in tough times. She also lost many dear friends to the AIDs epidemic in the 80s, and cherishes one of them in a special chapter of this book.

This is a fun read, and is certainly a book you won't want to put down! Her writing is lively and personable, like she's right there in the room with you, talking about her life.

title: Great Book - Excellent Series.
text: Part Two of the Hell On Earth series and a great follow up to Part One, The Gates.  I enjoyed that book so much I started Legion straight away after finishing it.  This book gives us another look at how the gates of Hell opening on Earth went for some people not featured in the first book.  We also get a bit more background story on a few we met briefly in the previous book.  Things are getting worse for the human race as the death toll rises frantically without very little anyone can do to stop it.  Iain Rob Wright always delivers for me and this book is no exception.  It’s a fantastic apocalypse horror story jammed full of divergent characters from all over the world.  If you've not read The Gates do so as this will make much more sense having done so.  As I said when I reviewed Part One I don’t usually like a series that splits the story over several books but with this author I was willing to give it a go.  I wasn’t disappointed and recommend this book and its wider series very highly, just be ready to read the next book too!

This book started slow...I found myself waiting for the action to start...lots of speculation going on that had no basis...not the smart Jack Reacher we have grown to know.  It was a page filler as opposed to a page turner of a book.

title: funniest of the series
text: Death of an Italian Chef is the 14th book in the Hayley Powell Food and Cocktails Mysteries, written by author Lee Hollis. I've read all the previous books and received a copy from NetGalley for this installment. Now that I'm caught up and ready for the 2022 release, I did a bit of research on the author and her other series... since I only began reading this one because it appeared in a collection of novellas that all took place in Maine, a state I want to eventually live in one day. Imagine my surprise when I learned Lee Hollis is not a real person, rather a brother and sister writing duo. Wow! I hadn't expected to learn that, but it doesn't change much about the books for me. It might explain why occasionally I see a bit of repetition in a tale, i.e. someone introduced a character in one chapter and then introduced them again in another. Nonetheless, it was a great book in the series... possibly my favorite and the funniest to date. At the same time, it ruined a character for me because it turned him into a pampered baby. It was meant to be funny but was the wrong person to apply the logic to in my opinion. It was better off for Hayley's son, not her brother who is supposed to be a role model. Features great Italian recipes, and some cocktails that I really want to try. Ends with a fun surprise too. Looking forward to the next one!

title: The Bookmark Blog for Off the Record
text:
Lately I have been into sports themed books. Don't know what it is exactly, but they are my favorite thing! I especially seem to love hockey books, which is funny cause I don't even watch that many hockey games! So, when this one came along, I was excited.... for some reason, it seemed like just what I was looking for. A great romance and hockey mixed in.

And I was right!

Ever is excited when she first meets Linc, he seems like exactly the opposite of most athletes, almost too good to be true. And then she catches him in what she thinks is exactly what she expects him to be doing, and, with admittedly, her feelings hurt, she writes a scathing article about it. Linc decides to get his revenge and asks for Ever to be his assistant for the next six weeks, to learn about him and what he is really like, and right a true article about him. As you can imagine, it doesn't take long for those original sparks to start to fly, and well....

Yep, this one had a little bit of everything that I love in it. Romance, sports, passion... and I do mean passion! Man did they get angry with each other! But at the same time, they would always seem to work it out. I started in the middle of the series, but didn't feel that I had missed anything doing that. That said, I would love to read some of the other books in the series, because I really enjoyed this one and would love to read more by this author. I;ll have to look them up sometime.

BTW, this one would make an EXCELLENT beach read!

title: I loved this little read
text: I loved this little read. But, I may a little biased. Having a close connection with small town journalism and an on again/off again affair as a writer, this book really hit home. From finicky readers, to less than cooperative police and demanding advertisers, Rossignol nails all the "glamour" of small town journalism. Read along as a real life murder mystery unfolds and a regions incompetent and/or corrupt officials fall into chaos. It's a fun adventure for those who very know little about small town publications and a sad indictment for those who do.

title: Emotionally charged, heartfelt extremely special story
text:
This book was brilliantly written and beautifully portrayed. So much research went into this story. It was well thought out and M.E. Carter did an amazing job composing this story.

Jason, Addison, and Jax's story continue in Hart to Heart and you are immediately immersed into their world once again. A lot of love. A lot of tears. A lot of emotions. You will experience every emotion. That to me is what an amazing story consists of. This one pushes limits, but you will learn that what you think may be missed opportunities are actually blessings. Being at the right place at the exact moment you are needed to be there makes all the difference in the world.

I was deeply touched and moved by every word, sentence, paragraph and chapters. This story has quite an impact on me and is one that I will never forget.

M. E. Carter - I applaud you for this story and it's such an important one that needs to be shared. It's that special.

title: Wonderful Read
text:
If you're looking for a beautifully written and clean historical romance set in the 1850s, this one is for you. The characters touched my heart and made me feel as if I was a part of their little town in Mesquite Springs. Evelyn is a strong character who relies on her strengths and independence to make it through the good and bad situations in her life. Wyatt amplifies her persona with his good nature, quick thinking and humble atmosphere. Together they captured everything beautiful about a natural growing connection. Little Polly melted my heart with her desire to find the perfect daddy and overcome the loss of her family at such a young age.

I was surprised to find myself sucked into the history of Evelyn and Polly. I wasn't expecting the mystery surrounding the orphans and the heart squeezing trials of forgiveness. I found comfort in their inner struggles as they grew together. This novel was surprisingly action packed and left me guessing who "The Watcher" was as the plot unfolded. An overall easy read encompassing the ideals of 1850 small town life and the growth of family and friends through love and understanding.

I received this novel from Revell Reads in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. All opinions are solely my own. I recommend this novel for those who enjoy Historical Romance.

Reading the story from each Seth and Allegra’s POV allows you to become fully immersed in each character. It provides you with a raw look at how each person is dealing with their emotions, balancing the needs of the others in the relationship and maintaining their day-to-day lives.
Allegra has grown as a person but still needs answers. Seth wants to protect her and remove Theo for good. Theo is a total douche bag who will hopefully get what he deserves.

title: Juicing simplified for human consideration
text:
I am glad I read this book. While I have read other books on juicing and known much that was expressed in here, I was glad to discover a strong back up for my decision to blend more than juice. I do juice, just not as often. Dr. Clement at Hippocrates Health Institute is adamant that juicing is better for the body than blending the same ingredients into a smoothie. In this book I got the feedback that blending adds fiber which is very needed for the body. I felt I was making my body work harder because I was being more lazy (blending is much easier than juicing) but this book affirmed that both are good and getting fiber is nothing to look down one's nose on.

I can only say I'm a total believer who has felt the difference since adding juicing and blending to my life. I had alopecia for over ten years and in a year, my kale smoothies (I do believe it was because of them) has practically healed that situation...

Well written, easy to read and digest this very important material.

title: Brilliant!
text:
Endeared (Accidental Billionaires, book 5)

I am voluntarily posting an honest review after reading an ARC copy of this book.
I have mixed emotions with this book. I am so happy to finally get Owen’s story, but so sad because it brings an end to the Accidental Billionaires series. Endeared is book 5 in the Accidental Billionaires series. It tells the story of Owen Sinclair, the youngest of the Sinclair clan, and Layla, who was once Owen’s best friend. Owen, Andie (from Enchanted, Accidental Billionaires, book 4) and Layla were friends from school. Owen had feelings for Layla in high school, but did not say anything because he was afraid to lose her friendship, and as soon as he graduated he was leaving for medical school. Layla also had a crush on Owen, but never said anything because she did not want to lose his friendship. Layla has a horrible situation at home, and never shared it with anyone. As high school is ending there are events that happen to Layla, which ruins everything she had planned for herself after high school, and she fully blames Owen for these events. Owen has been away for years attending medical school and focusing on getting through his residency and has not really seen his family. He has tried to reach out to Layla, but has never heard from her. Ten years later and Owen is now a doctor and is returning home to Citrus Beach and will be taking over the clinic there, and much to his surprise, his high school friend Layla is the nurse practitioner there. He never really focused on his billionaire status; as he was too busy becoming a doctor. Now back home and Owen feels a disconnect with his family, does not know how to handle being a billionaire, and he really wants to find out why Layla hates him so much. That is all I am saying, so I do not spoil it for anyone. Endeared is everything I hoped for and more. The character development is perfect. You will be experiencing a lot of emotions with Owen and Layla’s story. J. S. Scott is an amazing author, and you can always count on drama, plans being hatched, groveling, hot steamy scenes, did I mention groveling, and a wonderful ending. I am a huge fan of J. S. Scott. I have read all of her books, and not one of them has left me disappointed. I highly recommend Endeared. A definite must read! You will not be disappointed. Thank you J. S. Scott for another amazing series. Cannot wait to see what you have in store for us next.

title: Mallory seems nothing like the shattered woman he rescued two years ago
text:
Mallory Baldwin is a survivor. A former victim of human trafficking, she’s been given a second chance, yet not a night goes by that she doesn’t remember being a slave to weapons dealer Dante Torres. Despite being afraid of the dark and wary of strangers, Mallory is trying to rebuild her life by turning her tragedy into redemption.
To former Navy SEAL Tennyson Walker, Mallory seems nothing like the shattered woman he rescued two years ago, and he can’t help but be inspired by her strength and resilience. So when a stalker suddenly makes Mallory vulnerable once again, Tennyson steps up as her bodyguard to keep her safe.
Mallory and Tennyson’s mutual attraction can’t be ignored, but neither can Mallory’s suspicion that Tennyson is keeping a terrible secret about her past. As the nightmare closes in, it’s not only Mallory and Tennyson’s love that comes under fire but their very lives as well. Will their faith sustain them? Or will the darkness win once and for all?

I loved this book. It had just the right amount of suspense to keep me guessing to the end. The characters are well developed. This is a story of two broken people who loved and trusted God. It deals with the aftermath of human trafficking and learning to love again with a great mystery. I highly recommend this book.

I received a digital copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for my honest review.

title: Delightfully Different
text:
Second Breath is a delightfully different love story. So used to the typical storylines in this type of genre, I was surprised by it's realistic and unique telling.
Dylan Rhodes is a charismatic and career driven up and coming lawyer.
Kama Ray is a psychology masters student working on her final thesis on how to become a Jedi in the world of online dating.
The two meet on one of Kama's final "thesis" dates. Kama believing Dylan to be the perfect test subject...and Dylan investigating Kama for unethical practices on said dates for his firm.
Either unsure of why they were both so drawn to one another. Each interaction with each other brings them closer together. There is a lot of miscommunication, trust issues, and angst to keep you reading just to find out how these two will work out their differences with such drastically different personalities. These characters are real and flawed which makes the intimate moments have a real depth and closeness to them. The massage scene had me swooning! Kama and Dylan definitely bring out the best in one another! This book is so refreshingly honest in Dylan and Kama's relationship. A fantastic read and I can't wait to see what's next up for this author!
*I received an ARC copy of this book by the author for an honest review *

title: A Beautiful Story
text:
The "About This Book" in the Kindle edition really doesn't do this book justice.

I took two art classes in college, and since one was an honors class, we visited a lot of museums around Massachusetts (not all would be considered art museums, but were, in their own way). I came to realize how incredibly hard it can be to run one. While Dulcie curates a small one, this book touches on how hard it can be.

This is not to say this book is dull or unexciting. To the contrary, very early into the story, you become very involved. The quotes at each chapter's beginning should not be ignored. They bring lushness and depth to the story. Perhaps want to see some the works of those quoted (I say as I peck out on my phone with a case depicting Starry Night).

The descriptions of Portland, Maine, do as well. They actually made me think of moving up there.

Believe me, up until the final chapter, you think you know Whodunit. The author may or may not have a few tricks up her sleeve until the very end.

Would I recommend this book? Very much so, especially to those who love a good murder mystery, and need to get away from the grittiness of big city murders. This is a beautiful book, especially for a murder mystery.

title: An Entertaining Fictional Introduction to a 20th-Century Philosophy
text:
This novel was given to me as a gift. And what a gift it turned out to be!
It’s no small enterprise to dramatize a complex philosophy in fiction form and do it entertainingly as well. Yet, in his new novel The Prometheus Frontier Kevin Osborne has ingeniously accomplished both. By setting his tale in a fantastical sci-fi environment with time portals, futuristic holo-lasic technology, and “normal” transportation via private air vehicles (AVs) that fly and hover up-down-all-around like the playful “Long Birds” that occasionally grace the narrative with their beauty and charm.
And by sharing experiences of the main character, young Alek Rankil, the story takes us on an historical and present-day exploration both physically and socially of a miraculous island named Arête--the Greek word meaning “excellence and moral virtue.” Alek is chosen to become one of the leaders of this diminutive Caribbean retreat, so he must learn about the genesis of its formation, its foundational principles, and its future plans to secure and administer a fully consistent, fully free “country” before accepting or refusing the mission offered to him and becoming a member of the Paine Society (named after American patriot Thomas Paine, who declared: “We have it in our power to begin the world over again”). This clever plot line executed by use of the in-and-out-of-time portals coupled with back-in-reality scenes for factual information and exciting experiences, of course, gives readers the opportunity to learn right along with Alek.
Giving obscure names to the huge cast of larger-than-life but believable characters, Osborne prevents us from discerning the origin, background, or ethnicity of most of them; thus, the whole population in the novel takes on an international flavor, making the theme of “liberty and reason” as necessities for mutual civility and personal happiness a universal one. Subtly personalized throughout, these ground-breaking pioneers of the spirit are no cardboard characters spouting philosophy like Ivory-tower donkeys laden with books; they live and love just like real-life individuals, and we get to know them as superbly intelligent but sensitive souls to care about.
The novel is saturated with science—microbiology, DNA Nanoscience, bioweaponry, and more—but each discipline has its part to play in this intellectual drama that delights the eye as much as it challenges the mind by including fascinating illustrations (the author also is an artist) both on the cover of the book and punctuating the text inside, all rendered with esoteric Chinese ink brushes to add a bit of light whimsy to the deeper conceptual theme.
Arête flies its flag of freedom bearing an image of the actual “Perpetual Flame” that burns eternally in its harbor in tribute to the Fire that the great titan Prometheus brought to humans in Greek mythology. When the flame turns color, inhabitants know by that signal that their tiny haven has been attacked. . .but by what and from whom they must now discover.
We are given hints early on by introductions to a philosophically opposite—totalitarian-collectivist-- society named the One World organization and known as “Pangaia” (Greek for “All Earth”) that its operatives may be the culprits. But the damage already done is massive and increasing by the minute with imminent death at everyone’s door, so time is of the essence not only to create a rapid method of defense but also to find the source of the thousands of fatal “weapons” threatening extinction and the perpetrators who created and unleashed them.
The stakes are high and the tension is tight in this novel of ideas turned skillfully into an action film that pits not just a good and bad guy against each other but makes the outcome of the conflict monumental because it’s two philosophies of life itself that are clashing before us on our mental movie screen.
The scope of crossing from past to present to future is a real achievement as Osborne charts a path from ancient Greece to tomorrow. It’s a long and ideationally thorny path but he makes us believe that the arduous journey is worth it, and he helps by identifying, targeting, and showing why and how to philosophically obliterate the ever re-sprouting thorns of piercingly injurious ideas to happiness and human welfare in order to (at last) clear the way to “a most excellent place.”
All in all, this ambitious “philosophical thriller” is told in high style by a historically knowledgeable, imaginatively thinking, truth-seeking, romantic wordsmith who delivers his mighty subject with great humanity and the gentle touch of a poet. I can’t help but think that along with others who will be introduced for the first time to this life-affirming-modern-age-philosophy via such a captivating novel that the brilliant woman who originated the actual philosophy being explored in a sci-fi setting might well have enjoyed the fictional ride as much as I did.

title: Beginning a new adventure
text: Ms. Hambly has very strict rules for magic in her novels. One of the rules is that a wizard must pay minute attention to all the small things of life, and she follows that rule in this book as its author. She has an uncanny knack for painting light in words that I have never witnessed in another author. She grows this world with the minutia of all the senses; sight, sound, smell, taste, touch. She never neglects emotions, and by the time the action takes place, we are invested in the characters and the world and can feel what they feel.

title: Mafia RH with a heck of a cliffhanger
text:
⭐⭐⭐⭐/5
🌶🌶🌶/5

This is book 2 in the "Five Families" Series. This story picks up from the cliffhanger that we were left with at the end of book 1.

This book had it all! Action, spice (that scene after the shower), and drama. Penelope has a way of writing chapters and scenes that are very descriptive and immersive. You can picture the scene, feel what the characters are feeling, and it makes it so satisfying to read. In this book, Maddie is starting to decide that what she truly desires is to have all four of these men in her life.

Matteo, Dante, Leo, and Aries (who we find out is named Rafe) absolutely deliver in this story. I adore that Penelope writes all her RH's in multiple POV. You really get a peek into how they are feeling, what they are thinking, and see how infatuated they truly are with Maddie.

Just like with book 1, Penelope Black hands us a cliffhanger, that has you begging for more. I can't wait to read #3.... Vicious Reign and see what happens next!

title: The tone of “The Hunt” for Vulcan is light and reads more like a who dunnit rather than a science book
text:
‘The Hunt for Vulcan’ blends Newtonian and Einsteinian physics in a way that is understandable and accessible demonstrating the impact that these two greats of Science had on the modern world.

The book begins in 1684 with Edmund Halley and progresses through to Albert Einstein. In summary, Mercury's orbit is irregular, and astronomers thought an unknown planet was responsible for exerting influence on it. Hundreds of man-hours were spent over a couple of hundred years looking for the elusive heavenly body, which was dubbed "Vulcan." It wasn't until Einstein's theory of relativity could be tested during a solar eclipse that the mystery of Mercury was solved.

The tone of “The Hunt” for Vulcan is light and reads more like a who dunnit rather than a science book. It’s a great book for those who are interested in history, science, exploration or astronomy.

Book supplied by Netgalley.

title: Best book Christopher has written yet!
text: I loved The Red Bikini but this book is even better! A sexy, romantic and consuming read with characters you feel like you know. I couldn't put it down.  I loved the tension and anticipation between Lia and Evan. He was just the kind of hot and unapproachable guy that women always seem to go for. I also love that the Sandy Cove books take place in Southern California so you can picture and imagine the places Christopher uses in her books. It was a thoroughly enjoyable read. I know a book is great when I'm sad it's over. Lauren Christopher is one of my favorite authors. I can't wait for the next book!

title: told me to do it just started to get better. I am not a smoker or a alcohol ...
text: This book is a must read if you suffer from migraines. I thought I was doing nothing wrong. It came down to the simple truth that I was eating and drinking my head to death. Coffee, Tea, all the caffeine I was putting into my body was hurting me every day. It took a few days to get it out of my system but when I stopped eating and drinking the things the Dr. told me to do it just started to get better. I am not a smoker or a alcohol drinker so that was not a problem. I did take about 12 adil a day. I had to stop that to. That was the hard part, going cold turkey with not pain meds. Thank you Dr. Daniel M.D..  I look forward to your next book.
