text:
The end the fire series is here and not only do we see Liam and Gen’s duet conclusion, but we get the back story to Liam and crazy Cristina’s past. At first the flashbacks didn’t make sense to me, but then I understood how the author was teeing us up to the culmination of how Liam came to be the man he is today. But love that he turned into a total cinnamon roll for Imogen, who was not the wilting flower everyone made her out to be. The book had a lot going on and it’s a longer read, but the slower burn is with it and I’m now over here hoping some of the supporting cast spins off to their own series!.

I received a free copy of this book via Booksprout and am voluntarily leaving a review.

title: Another Great Read from Howey
text:
This is the 12th I've read by Hugh Howey and I have to say, despite my love for SF, this may well be my favorite...in part perhaps because I well remember my own teenage travails and the feelings of being alone in a crowd at school.

Beyond that, however, I find the characters compelling -- and like most of my favorite stories, there's that bittersweet feeling at the end of the journey, the satisfaction of finishing a story well-told, but the longing to spend just a little more time with these "friends" we've found on the pages.

The Hurricane, like all of Howey's work I've had the pleasure of discovering, is well worth taking a look!

title: Amazing read, and highly recommended.
text:
K.I. Lynn is a FANTASTIC storyteller. Weaving her words in a way that keeps you so captivated you're done with the book before you blink. You're so lost in her world, the characters and their story; its nearly impossible to recover from it. And then you realize..you have to go back to the real world.
Welcome to the Cameo Hotel is one of those books that you get completely lost in. I couldn't put it down, I was so captivated. Gavin and Emma's story was intoxicating. It was unexpected in all the right ways. The sexual tension was dripping off of my e-reader. Their chemistry and dynamic with one another was so magnetic, I inhaled every single word deep down to my bones.
Gavin is an up and coming CEO staying in the hotel where Emma is the reception manager. What could possibly happen between these two? They're complete opposites, it seems. Both in life and on the social scale. But the more you read and get to know these characters, you find yourself seeing that they're the same in so many ways.
Gavin Grayson. What. A. Man. Self-assured, demanding, arrogant, completely alpha and yummy. You know those smoldering, sexy types - ones used to getting their way? Yeah. Imagine that tied up in a beautiful, sexy package. *sigh* Can Gavin be mine?
And Emma. She has to be one of my favorite characters. She's independent, smart, strong, loyal and so incredibly likable. The type of girl you want as your best friend. I fell in love with her spirit and tenacity. When these two collide, the fire sparks, and there is no turning back.
Welcome to the Cameo Hotel is a GREAT read. Gavin and Emma's story was unexpected, wonderfully written, with the best characters. It had everything to keep you entertained, and brought out the feels. Happy, anger, angst, kindle-melting sexual tension. Seriously. Super steamy. Funny!

title: S knows that p? Maybe!
text:
I bought this book for supplemental reading while taking a upper division course in epistemology. I referred to it while writing papers. The essay regarding Nozick's tracking theory was very helpful in one of my papers. After completing my course, I re-read the book. Following is my review.
Prima facie the book gets a five start rating. However, the book has some short comings along with the content that is very good. It would be a very difficult task to write a short introduction of any subject that has its origins and roots tied to Plato (Theaetetus). It would be especially difficult since the subject matter has an on going debate to this day thanks to Gettier. My epistemology class was a ten week term meeting three times a week. That was thirty hours of study and lecture by a PhD philosopher. Our course content only hit the high notes of well known philosophers (Plato to Quine). So based on the scope and nature of A Short Introduction it gets five out of five stars.
Not having a chapter on “The problem of Induction” and not mentioning David Hume is the only major short coming of this book.

title: Uniquely funny and surprisingly satisfying
text:
REMEMBER, REMEMBER...

Intrigued by Michael Dirda's praise in the Washington Post, I ordered and read this book,
"Memento Mori," Muriel Spark's 1959 novel about Brits coping with old age and death.
A classic indeed.

As a woman of a certain age, I found "Memento Mori" appropriate, as I had found "The
Prime of Miss Jean Brody" when I was considerably younger. It was "weird" to be sure,
but uniquely funny and surprisingly satisfying.

I look forward to reading "The Informed Air," Spark's latest and, sadly, final memoir.

Kathleen L. C.

title: Love it! Fascinating story that just gets better and better

WoW! What a book! Loved it! The story is so magnetic and it just drew me in even more. It's written so beautifully it's like I felt like I'm experiencing everything that is going on on each page. The plot just gets better and better and the suspense is amazing. This is one book I could not put down once I started it. I enjoyed it even more than the first bok in the series, Stealthy Steps. I love the whole concept of the nanomites. And the characters are just brought to life by the writing style. Love Gemma. Love the nanomites. Want to punch Cushing in the face. Love Dr Bickel. It's a fascinating series. I'm longing to read the next book in the series now - Stealth Retribution- to see what happens next. I'm so excited that it's coming out soon. Can't wait for book 3 to be out!
* I received a copy of this eBook in exchange for an objective review. *

title: Good collection of books.

title: Amazing and creative collection.
text:
The Stregoni Sequence is an amazing collection of three books. I cannot fully express in words how much I loved this series. I really enjoyed having all the books in my hands so I could read story after story.
I dare to say that in my opinion, these books will definitely live forever in the minds and hearts of fantasy fans everywhere, as it happened to me.
These stories bring with them a real chaotic flow of emotions and I feel still in shock from it all. I cannot tell readers how many times during this set of books I found myself holding my breath, quite literally.
The plots are very interesting and full of twists and turns that made me feel excited until the very last page.
I recommend this series to anyone who enjoys this kind of reading.

title: Quintessential Zombie Book
text: Outbreak (The Dark Days Series Book 1) by Christopher Cole is a zombies gone wild book told from a young boy's point of view. It's a hackneyed trope, there's no doubt about that but Cole doesn't try to sell it as anything else. If you want zombies, that's what you get. Zombies, zombies, and more zombies. There's a lot of people out there who live for this sort of thing, though personally, after reading it, I'm going to go on to something fresher and less cadaverous. Something that's a bit more lively, more animate, and less dead.

title: 50 ★stars★
text:
If I could give Winter Wolf 50 ★stars★..it still wouldn't be enough because it was just that charmingly entertaining and A+ for original content.

It hit on all my elements and for me..was a writer/reader chemistry match made in heaven. Understated humor that some might not be able to fully appreciate, as it's subtle but just enough. And the names..for once (oddly) I found them crazy-compelling. My next dog is going to be named Axton.

I'm not very shifter-friendly and tend to shy away from such reads..as they seem to be churned out in far too alarming frequency in Twilight-cult-like-volume..so I'm often mistrustful of such things.

But this one had that wonderful..just-out-of-the-dryer warmth and fresh-laundered fragrance I've come to recognize when a writer might be onto something..and I appreciated it immensely.

This will be only my second shifter book that I was able to embrace within the first few pages (1st being [book:A Thread of Deepest Black|9912767])..so really nice job..and great catch.

title: Shock, awe and did she really go there???
text: Oh dear Lord. What did I just read? If I hadn't found out there are 2 more books coming in this series I would have cried myself to sleep last night. Just wow. Strap on your seatbelt and get ready for a ride you aren't expecting. All hell just broke loose and there is one shock after another. Prepare yourself for tears and more tears and yet blind hope still remains. As in all the books, the writing is perfect, the storyline is complex and the characters are so very real. This is definitely one of the very best long running series of it's type out there. Thanks heavens it isn't over yet. Fingers crossed for certain people in the next books. As an aside, thank you for keeping the books fairly priced in a series this long and outstanding. There are a few other ones that have priced themselves out of my range, so I really appreciate it.

title: Not sure I'll be able to finish it...
text:
This is, quite easily, the most boring book I've had the displeasure of reading. It is over long, and, halfway through, still appears to have no discernable plot.

Stephen King is notorious for "slow starts" to his novels, and while King didn't actually write this, I'm rather expecting the "slow start" to consist of 90% of the book's total length.

I've already purchased the third book, and I read a review indicating the last twenty pages aren't horrible, so maybe I'll be skipping ahead just so I can move onto the last one.

For the record, I *loved* Gwendy's Button Box, but this sequel is trash.

title: ... in Love" by Lisa Brown Roberts was a very sweet read that was fast and easy to read
text:
"How (Not) to Fall in Love" by Lisa Brown Roberts was a very sweet read that was fast and easy to read. I found myself to be addicted with this story. Darcy Covington's dad disappears and causes Darcy's world to go into chaos. Darcy seems to have a level head on her shoulders because she deals with everything going on in her life so well. I really wish I personally could handle things as well as Darcy.

I think this story was written really well. It was creative and fun. I loved the characters. I thought they were great. I felt like this was more of a coming of age story than anything. Each character has to go through something and has to conquer whatever is going on in their lives. I loved being able to watch the characters grow and become more mature versions of themselves.

It was very lovely to read a story that is pretty realistic. This story is so sweet. I just loved it. Getting to know each character was great. They were so much fun. Roberts is great at writing characters. I think the characters really made this book so I hope Roberts continues focusing on having fantastic characters.

title: Nice story
text:
Clay Denton was hired to find a US Marshal’s niece, Josephine Myers. Once he finds her, he will be hanged for crimes committed during the war.

Josephine Myers doesn’t remember much about her childhood as her family was killed by the man who now owns her. When Clay finds her, she’s afraid for both of their lives as Junior isn’t a man to mess with.

Clay and Josephine were meant for each other through destiny and divine intervention. Once they finally get a chance at love, will others get what they want and tear these two apart forever.

This was a good addition to this new series and I really enjoyed reading about Clay and Josephine’s adventure.

text:
This was my first book by Natasha Madison and it won't be my last. I also have her debut novel, Something So Right, and after reading Hell And Back I look forward to that as well.

This was an emotionally charged book that had me right from the beginning. Bella is such a lovable character and her selfless acts for her daughter, Lilah, are nothing short of beautiful. It is impossible not to fall in love with Jackson. He's soft and tender when he needs to be and dominating and supportive when he's looking out for others he cares about.

You become invested in their relationship between Bella and Jackson, as well as the supporting characters in the story. They all work wonderfully together. There are a few twists and turns I didn't feel coming so that made the story all the more intriguing.

This is a must read for 2016!

title: Luna and Beck + DOGS
text:
Luna is the kindhearted hippie of the Bluewater group and I love her. She worked hard to build her cruelty-free cosmetics company to what it is today, and is beloved by people all across America. She is genuine and it shows through her social media presence and branding, and that's why she is so popular. Until she is blindsided by a lying supplier, and her business starts crumbling almost as fast as her image shattered. 

Luna does some soul searching and realizes she lost sight of her values and decides to focus on giving. She is introduced to Beck's organization, Lucky Dog, and finds a cause that she really connects with. 

Watching Luna and Beck bond is so good. The two are complete opposites in every way, except in what they care about: helping the dogs. Luna is feeling battered by life, Beck has trust issues, but they somehow bring out the best in each other. She helps him become the leader his organization needs, and he helps her to find her strength again. 

This opposites attract story is a great read, but then add in all the wonderful dogs (you know they're my favorite) and this book is just incredible.

title: New book boyfriend
text:
Every time I read a book by Meghan Quinn I have a smile on my face. The Locker Room her newest book is a sports romance that will leave you with all the smiles, heartwarming feelings and fun and laughter that you have come to expect from her books.

The Locker Room is set on a college campus and is based on a baseball player, Knox, and new transfer student, Emory. Knox is good looking, fun and has never had a serious relationship. Emory is smart, beautiful and full of wit. Their first meeting is comical and filled with a whole lot of laughs. As they become friends, you will fall in love with them. Emory was hurt very badly previously and doesn’t want a new relationship. The chemistry and banter between the two will leave you feeling so happy. I say every time that I will savor this book, but you can’t help but keep reading. Knox is just so swoony and the best boyfriend ever!

Their relationship goes through its ups and downs, but you hope that they find their HEA. There are also some great supporting characters in this book that I hope will be the next books in this series in the future.

Meghan Quinn’s books are feel good, make you laugh, cry, and smile and just warm your heart. I definitely recommend getting to know Knox and Emory in The Locker Room!

title: These Are The Recipes You've Always Wanted
text:
Flipping through the pages of Simple Cake, I feel like Odette has given me a piece of her home. The pictures, descriptions, and recipes all feel personal and have been included in the book with love and care. These are the recipes you've always wanted. Ones that get handed down generation to generation. These are the ones you whip up in a jiffy because friends are popping by for a cup of tea. The ones you have on the counter and cut slices out of to nibble on all day. The recipes are not fussy and very versatile. Most of which you will have the ingredients for at home. I love that different ingredients can be swapped in and cakes can be paired with different toppings for a variety of variations of each cake. I tried the Versatile Coconut Cake (p.44) with Nana's Simple Glaze -Coconut variation (p.70). The cake was easy to make. I pretty much mixed it in one bowl. The cake was soft, moist, and flavorful. I ate a piece for breakfast with a cup of hot tea, then nibbled on a piece after lunch, then after dinner, and then poof it was finished. I can't wait to make the next recipe. I'm eyeing the Lovely Lemon Yogurt Cake (p.48), Tangy Olive Oil Cake (p.40), Milk and Honey Cake (p.36). All the toppings look and sound delicious.

Disclaimer: I received this book to review. This is my honest opinion of the book and recipes. I love it and it's not a book to be missed. Everyone who bakes should have it. Thanks for the free book, Ten Speed Press, and thank you for sharing your wonderful recipes Odette!

title: Good, Just
text:
In His Image digs deep into some of the major the characteristics of God and how we can and should be reflections of Him to the world. The book looks at God Most Holy, Loving, Good, Just, Merciful, Gracious, Faithful, Patient, Truthful, and Wise. Hopefully this doesn’t come as a shock to you, that even though we are created in His image, we are not (nor will we be) perfectly like Him. As sinners, we are in need of a Savior. While Jesus comes in and changes our hearts, we will still wrestle with sin in our life. That doesn’t mean we should embrace it or brush it under the rug as nothing, but it should be active in our minds to turn from our sins and strive to be more Christ-like.

Jen uses practical, real-life stories to explain deep, theological principles. Just as Jesus spoke in parables, we can begin to understand complex truths we don’t fully understand, when they are explained using stories we do. She also used plenty of scriptures to back up what she was saying. She gave God’s Word the ultimate authority and not merely our life understandings.

One piece that stuck out to me in the book was when Jen talked about our desire for God’s will in our life. How often do we go to God and ask Him “What should I do?” Not saying we should never pray that, but she poses that we should ask the question “Who should I be?” Our desire for God’s will in our lives should be more than just knowing what to physically do in this life, but about transforming our hearts to be more like Christ. She says “without meaning to, we can begin to regard our relationship with God primarily as a means toward decision making.”

I appreciate how the book was written to not only teach, but encourage and correct. First she shares about how God is each of the characteristics for the chapters. Then she shares both how we should and how we shouldn’t live, to be a better image-bearer of Him. She doesn’t pretend to be perfect herself, but instead shares her own flaws and need for Jesus. She also doesn’t shy away from sharing things we probably need to be actively convicted on to change in our lives (ex: patience). God doesn’t expect us to be perfect, but if Jesus has truly changed our hearts, it should change how we act and think in this life. Instead of living for ourselves, our eyes should be focused on God.

I highly recommend this study, and hope that it can be a blessing and encouragement to you as well 🙂

*I received a complimentary copy of this book from NetGalley and the author in hopes of an honest review. I was not obligated to give a positive review. Thoughts and opinions expressed are mine alone.

title: I didn't really start enjoying this book until  more than halfway through.
text:
I love adventure stories, and am particularly partial to those that feature the Amazon Jungle and River. By all rights I should have loved this story. It wasn't until near the very end, I began to actually enjoy STATE OF WONDER.

For most of the book, I really had a hard time finding any empathy for the shallow, self absorbed characters. Most of them are academics focused on their careers (trying to develop the can't-miss drug that will give women the ability to bear children much later in life.)

The author did turn things around for me in the last quarter of the book when an unexpected plot twist and a deepening friendship between the two main characters redeemed things, and made up for some of the plausibility and flow issues in the plot.

The main character, Marina, is, for most of the book, a shallow boring woman who, though clearly brilliant, keeps her relationship with her much older boss (a widower) hidden from everyone she knows. He has so little regard for her that he is willing to risk her life to raise stock prices in the drug company they both work for. He has no problem with this, even though one employee has already died, and his grand plan has little chance of success. Marina, who is hoping for a marriage proposal, appears pathetic and weak by allowing herself to be manipulated into something she does not want to do, and may end up killing her.

The background of Marina's life is partially conveyed to the reader by a constant flo-interrupting series of nightmares, that are neither frightening, interesting or even necessary. They just interrupt the pacing. I hate when women are conveyed as weak, and are easily manipulated by men who inevitably, take more than they give.

The other main female character is a rude ball-buster, who also followed a selfish man, right up until he died. There has to be a happy medium between a woman that won't stand up for herself and one that will not compromise or make any effort or concessions to anybody. Both are unflattering depictions of women and just not realistic. Both women were much more likeable by the end of the story, though they continued making poor choices.

If you want to really like STATE OF WONDER, you'll have to stick with it, because the ending is the best part.

title: Mike Reeves just gets it, then he passes it on to his readers.
text:
If you are wanting encouragement to come before the Father in prayer
Or if you don’t think you need to pray
Or if you don’t have time to pray then you should read this book.
With a sympathetic heart Mike shows us how important prayer is but there is no taking you on a guilt trip. He exhorts his readers to speak to their Father on the basis of the relationship that Christ has bought them into.

title: Plays too heavily on bad stereotypes to have a chance
text:
Do you ever have a vivid dream and wake up with it so fresh in your mind your thoughts are racing and you can "see" it? Yet, an hour later when you try and recount it, the recitation comes out like an early reader kids book? "I went there. I felt this. He did that, so I said this..."
That is what this story felt like, a great dream that lost its luster and depth in the cold reality of day. The characterization is shallow, visual world building non-existent, and a plot arc as appealing as week-old bread.

If you are a hockey fan, do not read this book. The author characterizes the male lead with implausible stereotypes related to professional athletes. The female lead, a pastry chef, gets the opposite treatment with almost no backstory. Their banter feels forced and the "chemistry" of their interactions falls flat.

The plot feels both rushed and contrived. Major hurdles are resolved in a couple of pages or by the end of the chapter. Secondary characters are weak with the possible exception of Riley. They add no fun moments & do not facilitate the main characters' growth/development. Finally, every minor hurdle or twist is very predictable.

To be fair, the book is very well edited and formatted; no typos and limited grammatical mistakes are present. I really don't understand all the positive reviews. If I had read this book as a teen, I might have enjoyed the story for the "it could happen" daydreams. As an adult reader, who has an impossible time walking away from a book once started, I wish I had never downloaded this book. In short, just don't waste your time or money on this effort.

title: interesting fantasy
text: 3.5 stars. The blurb for this books was very offputting and not at all how the book unfolded. Sharon Shinn does such a nice job of building interesting fantasy worlds. We follow several main characters as their lives intersect in sometimes surprising ways, in how they come to save the world.

title: Strong female chatacters combined with lots of unexpected twists!!!!!
text: Wow, what a great story.  As the book opens, the reader is introduced to a widower and his young daughters who are on the threshold of womanhood.  This novel follows the challenges, successes, disappointments, and choices of the three sisters, each of whom is distinctly different from each other.  While they share a bloodline and some common beliefs, the surprises life throws their way create personal challenges, that quite often surprise the reader.  Set in the 1890s in a small isolated European village, the young girls blossom into women as they confront the fate that life throws them.  The initial chapter was so predictable I almost put the book down, but several chapters in I was hooked, and before I finished this first book, I ordered book two.  Definitely geared for an adult female audience, Durst-Benning's writing sets it apart, and at times the reader felt like she had a love/ hate relationship with each of the three sisters.

title: Could not put it down
text:
An amazing achievement of meticulous research and well chosen interviews of men who were there.
These interviews accompany a description of certain events about getting onto and capturing Omaha Beach.
The stories that are told as these heroic men and, yes, boys relate their experiences are heart wrenching.
I have often heard that DDay was in many ways a debacle and near disaster saved only by the grit and raw courage of the Army infantry and this author explains why and how that is true.
I am moved even now writing about what I have learned and read in this book.
On another point, I read this while experiencing the Coronavirus quarantine in April, 2020. This book helped put our minor discomforts into perspective.

title: Young & Simple
text:
Well, I'm torn. I picked this up because of another Review that compared it to one of my favorites, "Crown/Court Duel". This book definitely has many of the same winning combinations as CD, but with only one book some of he better aspects are rushed or replaced by the greater fantastical world-building. If it hadn't been for the shining praise and my similarly high expectations, I probably would have liked this much more. As it was, I still finished it in a day.

Back to the comparison: There is definitely a court setting, political intrigue and balls that one would expect. Sometimes, though, the politics are confusingly at once superficially treated and at the same time unavoidably important to the plot. I found myself on more than one occasion confused by character's partial statements and the myriad of important figures and their positions.

While the heroine is spunky, independent and definitely likeable, it would have been nice to see a little more wit and or banter--the second half of the book's more serious nature didn't seem to allow for this though. Finally, along those lines, while there is some romance, most of the book is taken up with the heroine's blatant refusal to marry and her following refusal to flirt. In the end, then, it seems more geared to a younger reader due to the storyline's simplicity--think of a Jane Austen-like quick resolution. The tightly wrapped up ending accentuates this feeling of simplicity despite some absolutely horrid creations of character that evoke real feelings of hatred in the reader.

A recommended light read, but not as good as CD.

title: 4.5 dark, twisted, stunning stars to Josie Litton's His Lordship's Downfall: Part One.
text:
4.5 dark, twisted, stunning stars to Josie Litton's His Lordship's Downfall: Part One.

I'm a newly acquired fan of Josie Litton's, but now that I've found her, I want to devour all her books in one sitting. As always, Litton has a way of weaving beautiful words with a compelling, edgy story that isn't for everyone. She mentions that this is her darkest story yet, and I truly think she shines brightest when she's delving into this world. Such stunning writing style paired with such rich, developed characters -- her work is an absolute delight.

I found the main character, our fiendish Lord, to be appropriately terrible, but in a way you can connect with him. Given his social standing, the laws of the time (set in the (not so?) distant future where Britain and Japan control the whole world), the status of his "pet", and his innate interest in bondage, humiliation, and sadism, you can really see why he acts and thinks as he does. Every delightfully wicked thought made perfect sense to me, no matter how twisted or disgusted I felt regarding said thought personally.

What I also loved was that the heroine, his pet, barely said more than fifty words in this whole piece, but she was, to me, a wonderfully developed and interesting character in her own right. I look forward to seeing her role expanded upon in the follow-up book.

Speaking of which... Although the book is very sexual, there is an underlying plot that, once it gets going, you can't turn away from. For a while, I found things a bit repetitive: go to London, intense sex scene, go to London, another intense sex scene. But when the subplot started to surface, when the politics between the Lord and his wife arose, well... I couldn't read it fast enough. Never mind that the sex scenes, while explicit and frequent, were varied enough to keep my attention, but the rest of the story... Well, that made my heart race too.

Some warnings. This is extremely explicit. There is dubious consent in play. Detailed bondage scenes. I don't think this is for the faint of heart, and readers unfamiliar with darker works should heed the warning and go in with their eyes open. There is also a major, major cliffhanger. That being said, I am pleased that this story will (hopefully) be told in two parts. Yes, it can be frustrating to have a book broken up into smaller pieces, BUT I think Litton has provided enough of a read here that the novella is satisfying in its length.

Definitely a recommended read for those who can stomach the darker side of things. For me, this stands as erotica, not necessarily a romance, but things might change in Part Two. Can't wait!

I voluntarily (and happily) reviewed this work after receiving an ARC.

title: Finally un-forgotten!
text:
As a follower/fan of WWII history as told by those who lived it, I would highly recommend this book to other like-minded people. It tells of the young women, mostly college-educated, many of them teachers (like my own daughter) who seized the opportunity to work for our government, unaware of what they were being asked to do. They were codebreakers whose own families had no clue of the work they did until decades after the war ended, and sometimes not even then! Their work lead to the expedited end to both the war in Europe and in Asia. Many US citizens STILL don't realize the important cryptanalysis work they did. It's about time we teach our children (especially daughters) about their many, many accomplishments and sacrifices.

To say I enjoyed this book is an understatement! I highly recommend it!

title: A whirlwind adventure around the world and through time
text:
The Virgin of the Wind Rose grips you in its teeth and whirls you through history and around the world. As soon as State Department employee, Jaq Quartermane, is told of the tragic death of her fiancé in Ethiopia she is dragged into a terrifying investigation rooted in the tales of the Knight Templars and the voyages of the explorers sponsored by Prince Henry the Navigator.

Finding herself in peril inside an ancient rock hewn Ethiopian church, does she trust to her deep Christian faith or to Elymas, an agnostic rascal? And it is trust and conspiracy which underline this thrilling adventure, taking Jaq from Rome to France, Portugal and Israel.

While Jaq and Elymas try to solve the SATOR square, an ancient palindrome, their travels are paralleled by the story of three young 15th century Portuguese boys. Meeting in alarming circumstances, Pero, Zarco and Dias form a bond which carries them through their difficult training at the Tomar observatory and sustains them in their navigational test at Prince Henry’s fort in Sagres. Split apart by the different missions they are given, their friendship is maintained and their actions will have repercussions throughout history.

I was fascinated by the details of early exploration, which has always interested me, and the further involvement of Christopher Columbus add to the intrigue. At the same time, I was anxious to continue following the mysteries and dangerous situations explored by the present day couple. Glen Craney has made their relationship suitably prickly and intense, given their very different backgrounds, but he has allowed their humanity and understanding to shine through.

I loved Craney’s acerbic wit in comments such as, “The priest was obviously one pew short of a full congregation.” Naturally this novel will be compared to the books of Dan Brown but the quality of writing in The Virgin of the Wind Rose has the edge for me. Almost the best part is the last chapter with so much promise and fascinating clues.
I was given a copy by the author in exchange for an honest review

title: A well-done second chance romance!
text:
Second Chance at Us is a standalone contemporary romance -- but Becca is Finn’s sister from In Trouble With Him! I love when those connections are made!

Fifteen years after Rebecca and Blake spent one amazing night together back in high school, they come face to face in the most unlikely of places. Neither one of them has forgotten the night they spent together, or the way that Blake blew Rebecca off. He's been carrying around a ton of guilt over how he ghosted her, always thinking of Rebecca as the one that got away. And Rebecca has been so emotionally damaged by that night that she hasn't let herself get close to another guy since Blake. But when fate offers them a second chance, will Blake be able to convince Rebecca to give him a fair shot?

I liked how this story unfolded. Rebecca was hesitant to get involved with Blake again, and her indecision really came through as she struggled in trusting him again. And then when it came back to bite her in the butt, she knew her instincts had been right. I really liked that particular twist, because I felt that Blake's reasonings for blowing her off were kinda lame. I get that he was a nerdy 16 year old and she was a popular cheerleader... but the twist in the scenario made it all make more sense.

Overall, I really liked this second-chance contemporary romance. Blake and Rebecca are really likable characters, the story is well-written and unfolds nicely, and it all wraps up with a pretty HEA bow at the end! I'm guessing that this is the start of a new series featuring the rest of Finn's sisters, and I am all in for that! I received an advanced copy and voluntarily left a review.

title: Interesting worldbuilding, trying heroine
text:
BUT I still really enjoyed the book, so much so that I bought the second one today and will keep reading (I also bought it for my sister). Overall, I can say that I like almost everything about the book. The worldbuilding is interesting, as is the main conflict. However, Jashi is frustrating and tries my patience A LOT, so often, I find myself muttering at her to shut up or that she's being stupid, which can make one wonder how I could continue the story. Admittedly, if the other aspects of the book weren't enjoyable, I wouldn't have. So, I guess that says something...? Really, her only benefit is her genealogy. Nothing else about her is made much of except negative things. She's short-tempered, ignorant, not very bright, disrespectful, illogical, etc. Furthermore, to avoid spoilers, I'll just say that the thing that draws Jashi into doing something bad, that whole angle, in fact, doesn't make sense to me. It just seems like conflict for conflict's sake because it's not executed well.

Still, it's an easy read that is otherwise quite interesting! I'm particularly interested in the history, the world, the dragons, and the male lead. Honestly, Jashi is the weak point of the novel. So I appreciate when it switches to him. Don't get me wrong! I LOVE a good female lead; in fact, I'm specifically focused on buying books with strong, unambiguously black female leads (with vulnerabilities that keep them human -- think Mace from Strange Days), but maybe the writer confused strong/independent with pushy, reckless, and disrespectful. So, my fingers are crossed that Jashi quickly grows up in the second book. I'm about to start it now, so I'll have to let you know.

title: A return to form
text:
Warning--There are a few spoilers.

I was kinda nervous to crack this book open, not gonna lie. I was so disappointed in First Star and didn’t want to see more of the same. (Oh my god, was that really four years ago already? Holy cow.) But fear not! This felt like classic Phillips, and I adored it.

There wasn’t a whole lot I didn’t like. Only a couple things come to mind—the beginning was a bit slow and there wasn’t much of a hook to pull you in. Also, the whole dancing thing should have been nixed. It served no purpose except to illustrate that at the beginning, Tess danced because she was sad, then at the end, she danced because she was happy. There was zero dancing in between and dancing didn’t matter to any of the characters via career or hobby or fond memory or anything, it was just a useless and irrelevant plot device to tie in the title.

I not only liked the characters, I respected them and sympathized with their complicated, well-realized emotional struggles; I bawled hard and ugly when Tess had to give Wren up. I loved all the secondaries, too: the Winchesters, the teenagers—Psycho had two seconds of screen time, yet he oozed charisma and I still want to know more about him—the Phishes, the Dennings, and Eli’s family. Somehow, Eli was my favorite. He wasn’t around much, but I found myself very concerned for him, and I just wanted to wrap him in my arms, give him some bacon, and tell him he’s a good kid, doing a good job, and he’s loved.

I respected Phillips tackling a sticky, uncomfortable subject like teenage sex. I suppose some might feel it was too much like an agenda, too PSA-y, but that possibility didn’t occur to me until just now, because I was so wrapped up in the well-developed, three-dimensional characters that it didn’t feel like there was an ulterior motive, it just felt real.

I appreciated the setting, which was very familiar and relatable to me. I live on a rural acreage fifty miles from the nearest hospital, just like the characters, and while I’m lucky that the nearest town has an emergency response crew, if it didn’t exist, the nearest would be at least 15 miles away, just like in the story. I understand the small-town, traditionalist mindset, the intimacy, the ignorance, and the survivalists. If my dad, bless his heart, were fitter and liked his creature comforts less, he might have become a survivalist, holed up in a bunker with his guns and conspiracies.

I also appreciated all the research Phillips must have done to get all of the medical information correct. Well, I don’t actually know if it’s all correct, but I’d place a huge bet on it being as accurate as it could be. She gave enough detail for it to feel authentic; in no way was there so much that it felt like she was showing off how much work she put into her research. It just felt knowledgeable, realistic, intelligent, and responsible.

If I had to dig real deep for flaws, I would mention—what was her name? Heather Cooper or something like that. The wannabe Instagram queen. I don’t think she was fleshed out well; I still don’t understand why she was so cruel to Tess. Was it really just that her ex-boyfriend asked Tess out after he and Heather broke up? What was the point of that? She either should have been given a stronger and more relevant motivation or been cut.

But overall, I liked this book a lot. I’m not sure it’ll become a favorite that I regularly reread, like Breathing Room, Ain’t She Sweet, and Heroes Are My Weakness, but it’s not far behind.

I don’t know much about what’s next for Phillips, but I did read somewhere a little while back, probably on her Facebook page, that she started working on the next book right away, so we shouldn’t have to wait four years again. I would guess the normal two, or if we’re super lucky, perhaps one. *crosses fingers* Here's to hoping that book is equally good, if not better.

title: Absolutely wonderful fairy tale book!
text:
Reflections is more of a coherent novel than the original Indexing, which was a bit of a cross between a novel and an anthology. An old enemy is chaining story incursions together in ways that cause new and unique–and terrifying–consequences. Henry and her team are in the crosshairs, and she’s going to have to learn how to control her Snow White story rather than avoid it if she wants her team to survive the experience. We also get to find out a lot more about Sloane (the Wicked Stepsister) in this installment, as the bad guys decide that they can turn her the rest of the way over to villainy.

I thought Reflections was a little bit slow for me, but it’s still a fantastic book. I just can’t get over how unique and new McGuire’s ideas can be. She’s my new favorite author, and I’m thankful she’s as prolific as she is. I’ll have to alternate reading more of her books with other authors’ so I don’t become the-reviewer-of-Seanan-McGuire-books!

title: It will definitely get you thinking ...
text:
Ord's book is a good overview of the severe problems that humanity faces today. Ord's focus is on "existential" risk, defined as the risk of extinction or permanent collapse of civilization, downplays some serious merely catastrophic risks. For example, Ord argues that nuclear war and climate change, while catastrophic, are likely not existential risks. I agree with Ord that assigning probabilities is a necessary quantitative exercise, even though it is understood that some are rather subjective. To do that, you need to have a concise standard to define probabilistic event - and perhaps "existential" is as good as any even. "Catastrophic" will mean different things to different people, so it wouldn't be a useful standard for Ord's exercise.

That said, I believe his treatment of climate change understates that issue. For example, disruption of ocean circulation will have dramatic weather and climate impacts globally, not just some cooling in the North Atlantic as Ord supposes. Still, I agree that whether climate change is an existential risk (over the next 3-5 centuries) or merely catastrophic is a debatable issue. None of that diminishes the urgent need to deal with climate change, as I'm certain Ord would agree.

Engineered pandemic - that's nothing short of damned scary!

He did get me thinking about unaligned AI. Unaligned AI is perhaps the most difficult of the risk to quantify because expert opinions are divergent. Estimates of the arrival of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), range from 10 to 50 years, and even never. Nonetheless, people need to be thinking a lot more about the risks of AGI, and how AI will be impacting our society in general. Read Ord's book, and then read Stuart Russell's book Human Capatible on AI.

title: Great Cookbook/Highly Recommended
text:
So, I was offered this Kindle book at a discount for my unbiased opinion. I have to begin with my initial reaction which was: "Great...another diet cookbook...yawn." I was pleasantly surprised with this edition, however. The book is broken down into two parts. The first being a discussion about low-carb dieting and its benefits to both your metabolism and immune system. There is narrative with respect to the effects of losing weight and discussion dispelling some old diet myths and what we've always been taught about low-carb/low-cal eating. I was floored when I read that the average adult woman should only eat no more than 100 calories of sugar a day. That is only 6 teaspoons and as we know, sugar is hidden in everything now. The day I finished reading the book I prepared the Spinach Salad with Chicken and Raspberry for lunch and my husband and I loved the fresh, tangy take on the old spinach salad. Tomorrow night's menu will include the Grilled Summer Kabobs which also look delicious. I'm also ready to move on to the Pina Colada Smoothie and the Luscious Lime Cheesecake Tarts as well as the many Chinese recipes contained in this section of the book.

The second portion of the book deals with a Comfort Food Diet Plan. The best part of this section (after the recipes, of course) was the discourse at the end of the recipe portion outlining the fact that these recipes were designed with taste in mind. It further goes on to make the reader understand that "you do not need to eat foods you do not enjoy just to stay healthy." Isn't it time the diet industry finally came out with a sensible plan that teaches us to eat what we like while staying healthy? That is akin to having your cake and eating it too, isn't it? Since I had this morning off, I stayed home and tried the "Quick and Easy Sour Pancakes" for breakfast this morning. The recipe uses milk and vinegar to mimic the flavor of sour cream and the result was delicious. The Comfort Food section of the book contains a recipe for meat loaf and I have long been searching for a new meatloaf recipe. This book is well worth the money and I highly recommend it for the weight conscious and health conscious alike. I always count on Amazon reviews when shopping and I hope this one helps you with your decision.

title: Disappointing
text:
I was so grateful and excited to read this book because I honestly can't get enough of MC romance! Sadly, as soon as I started reading the feeling that this book wouldn't meet my expectation weighed heavily upon me, but I pushed through it because the feeling felt premature. My instincts were right, something was definitely off about this book and it rested solely in the heroine's character, Arianne.

In those first three chapters I enjoyed Jagger and Arianne's back and forth banter until their banter became more of a nuisance than entertaining conversation. It stopped being entertaining when Arianne continued to demean Jagger's love for her. He might not have said the words but the emotion was in ever action he dealt towards her. She was petty and loyal to a fault, and the fault usually resulted in others besides those she was loyal to to get hurt.

Jagger's feelings towards Arianne progressed naturally, but Arianne drove me up a wall with her constant need to take what Jagger offered and still be all about herself. She cried and fought to be treated one way, but showed, to me at least, that she didn't really know what she wanted. She was constantly blind to the fact that Jagger was giving her everything she was boo hooing about wanting out of life outside of the biker world, which showed her immaturity. Jagger deserved someone better than her, someone who wouldn't meet him in the same level of toughness but also in the strength of character. Their chemistry throughout the first couple of chapters was there and then it just fell off a cliff and died, even their sex scenes were bland to me.

Dawn became the character in this book that kept me reading, she was competent and loyal, two characteristics I need in a lead female character. She absolutely stole the show. I can't wait to read her story in Beyond the Cut, book 2 in the Sinner's Tribe MC.

title: 4.5 Stars - Entertaining Read!
text:
I really enjoyed this one a lot! I'm giving it 4.5 out of 5 stars. This review is for an ARC, and reflects my honest opinion.

I read Jock Row a few months ago, and loved the characters, so I wasn't sure I'd love this book as much. Newsflash: I did! We had dual POV again, and I loved both equally. This was an entertaining read, and there were some scenes that were fire! This focused on rugby for the sport, which was a happy surprise; although we only really saw one match, and it wasn't that detailed.

Kip was a little crass, and definitely hairy (he calls himself a hairy godmother after all), but I just loved his character! He was used a lot, so he was super cautious especially at the beginning of the book. Teddy was adorable, and I felt like we could be best friends. The connection between these two was great; I liked how they started out with a weird friendship/partnership.

I found myself laughing several times while reading this, so I'd say it was a romantic comedy. We don't meet that many people in this book besides the main characters, so we were pretty much focused solely on them. We met some of Teddy's friends, some of the jocks were mentioned, and Kip texted his sister a few times. I was expecting a bit more family after how big a part they played in the previous book, but these characters were more independent, so that made sense. I can't wait to read more books in this series!

title: Amazing story of the USSR. Not to be missed!
text:
This was a well written, clearly well researched, and thought provoking novel. I was hooked right from the start and even though this is almost 500 pages, this book never released its claws.

This story was an intense story of love, loss, poverty, sacrifice, and what we would do for those we love. This is the first book I have read about the USSR and I found it both fascinating and terrifying. I felt like I was there, in the thick of it with Lena and Darya. The choices they were forced to make were horrible and I can’t imagine living like that. I give my complete respect for all those who suffered such horrible fates.

I absolutely loved Lena. She was such a strong and capable woman and she endured so much in her life. She never seemed to quite understand how much strength she truly had, but she was always humble and I loved that about her. She was given a tough lot in life and she just kept her head down and endured. I learned so much from her story and I hope to be a little more like Lena.

This story is one that can’t be missed. I would recommend this to anyone. Those who love history would especially enjoy this read. This is the first book I have read by Neville D. Frankel but this will certainly not be the last.

*I received an advanced copy of this book from the publisher. A positive review was not required. All opinions are my own.*

title: Striking depiction of loving and honoring others
text:
I felt like I was there with the author’s, as she is moved with dealing with her loss of her father and a fulfiling a promise in order to honor him.

I loved that the author didn’t shy away from talking about systematic problems, the Structural racism and problems within the welfare system. She painted such a vivid picture of the different boys in the story.

This book gave me a new appreciation for people working within the child welfare system and also a poignant look at what one could do to help further the cause. As Liz explains there is never enough help for the 450,000 of children in foster children here in America.

“Many children age out of foster care and with little support and guidance they are released and expected to have it together while all the while dealing with complex traumas.”

Finishing this book has me reconsidering fostering. I have four children of my own and some with extra needs, but thinking about the harsh realities that foster kids have lived through is heart breaking. This book made me think about what truly is family and how food can be used to warm others hearts. I think its one of my favorite memoir so far!
-Lorin R. Hayes author of Camouflaged Love: A Memoir

I swooned so much for Luke. That man is so darn sweet!! He is perfect for Scarlett after everything she has been through. Gosh these two are the cutest. Scarlett is so quiet and the past has made her who she is today, but she is strong, even if she doesn't see that. She is an amazing heroine in my eyes. The chemistry between these two was sooo hot. It was just sizzling there on the pages.

I cried in this one, I couldn't help myself. I was so invested in everything that was happening that It felt so real to me. I love escaping into a book like this. I need more words from this author like I need air! This book... NO, this series is a MUST READ! I absolutely love it and hope you will too!

Behind bars for the murder of an unsavory pirate, Bruce protests his innocence, and although things are looking grim for him, there’s a host of other suspects with more reason to put the pirate down.

When Annie, a social media personality with the "talent" of eating on camera, is threatened, then almost killed, Camryn delves into the world of mukbang to discover who wants Annie dead. Camryn's life is further complicated by her inmate father being released from prison, and her renewed feelings for her past boyfriend Wes. Does her father have an agenda that isn't in her best interests? Will Wes stick around or just hurt her again? Can Camryn solve the mystery of who wants Annie off the air? title: Great read!
text:
Clint has retired from the military and started a gun shop and shooting range. He's a solitary guy and likes his life without a lot of baggage. At least that's what he thought. Things change the moment a sassy little Latino with a toddler on her hip walks into his store to buy a gun.
Leila needs to protect herself and her son from her ex-husband who just got out of jail. He still believes they belong to him and will stop at nothing to get them back. Clint's shop is her first step in doing just that. She's instantly attracted to him, but the last thing she needs is to drag him into all her drama and danger. When he offers more than a gun for protection, she's very tempted.
I loved this story! The characters are strong and unique with good background development. The story is well told and was a true joy to read.

title: Dark, mysterious plot but it just didn't work for me.
text:
The beginning was an interesting setup. A-typical ballet dancer touring Europe at her last performance. She has a run in with a mysterious, handsome stranger. She is returning home but has lost contact with her family. She returns home to find her past erased. Gone. No one knows her, except mysterious hunk who happens to have found her across the Atlantic ocean.

Intriguing, yes?!
Things go a little wonky from here.

Turns out, mysterious stranger doesn't have the answers either. He is having the same life-erase issue.

Then we find out they have matching tattoos and conveniently found a diary that has a story similar to theirs AND they read it together.
This diary, which is written similar to a paranormal romance, complete with dialogue and inner dialogue felt too much of a gimme. A plot device, spoon-fed to the reader.

I really wanted to like this story. The setup was good, the plot was interesting but there wasn't enough natural build up to make this a page turner.

This is FREE and has 100+ 5 star reviews on Amazon, so don't let me stop you from checking it out. :)

title: Speechless
text:
Wow. Just wow. I thought going into this that I was in for maybe a good story padded with a lot of sex. Which, don’t get me wrong, I love those too. But this story turned out to be so much more, full of depth and raw emotion.

The characters in this story were amazingly well-crafted. I loved the dual first person POVs... it was so right for this book. Being able to see inside their thoughts and experience their emotions at such a powerful level was impactful. These characters were so different but then also somehow shared a lot of the same angst.

The story itself was a unique new take on this forbidden scenario and I was pleasantly surprised with it. I loved how the authors managed to inject so much of the hero’s faith into the story without it seeming preachy or over the top. It struck the perfect chord. There were twists and turns in this book that kept you invested and reading more.

The writing was beautifully done, raw and intense. I loved the characters’ separate journeys and this ended exactly the way it was supposed to. I can’t believe I’d never heard of these authors before but I can promise you they’re most definitely on my radar now. This was deep, compelling, romantic, raw, tragic, touching, and just an unforgettable story. I’m wowed.

title: Last Knight
text:
I really like the series so far.

In this instalment, Conner finds himself in prison in Taran. Their prison though is basically the Colosseum of old with gladiators fighting with other gladiators from the other quarters of the Colosseum.

The Knight fighting style is very reminicant of idea of Medieval Knight which base their techniques on brute strength. (Medieval Knights didn't really fight this way)

The style that the Sak'Hurai has feels very similar to the Samurai (the art that I am most familiar with). Just just with two katanas instead on one.

I find it hard to believe that the Taran empire, who is the richest nation known in this universe, Centurions have the worst fighting skillset when they could spent a lot of money on the art of war. They also have been at war the longest in this universe. More than two hundred years. I would have thought that in that situation they would have mastered the art of fighting and warfare must more than any other nation. Especially with the competition between the East and West companies. The Taran empire feels very Roman.

Deceiver = Devil
One god = God

Very fimiliar concepts there.

I also felt the pacing to be a bit off for my liking, but that might just be me.

title: While Jonquils for Jax is echantingly sweet, Marry Me Mad is delectably hot!
text:
I loved Jonquils for Jax.
I really liked Marry Me Mad!
Both books are part of The Rousseau Series but both can be read as standalone. These two books are beautiful in different kind of way that readers will surely enjoy. While Jonquils for Jax is enchantingly sweet, Marry Me Mad is delictably hot. Forget the sweetness of Jonquils for Jax for a while because this book is more spice than sweetness and Katy delivered them well. And oh my gosh. CORT. The banters between him and Mad brought a lot of smiles on my face. I was surprised most of the times because I kinda found myself smiling more times than I can count. And if you want a sexy read with humor and wit, you won't be disappointed. My favorite is the harp scene. You got to read the book to find out. It's one of the hottest scene I've ever read in a romance books. Katy leveled up the hotness and I bet most of the readers will love it!

In Marry Me Mad, I instantly fell in love with Cort. Knowing he's an Ambler who are known to be the blacksheep of the Blueberry Lane, added more allure to the personality of this thoughtful, beautiful, and talented soul. Here is a tattooed man who plays piano and harp and has the kindest and the softest of hearts.

Madeleine Rousseau or Mad for short, is Jax's twin sister. If you already read Jonquils for Jax, then you know that Jax is the sassy one, the socialite twin, the popular award winning producer in Hollywood and the opposite of Mad. Mad is a librarian, the gentle, sweet and pristine Rousseau sister. But underneath her proper clothes and elegant pearls is a wild woman waiting to be unleashed.

I had a glimpse of Mad and Cort in Jonquils for Jax but I didn't see the real Mad until this book. I know she was the sweet sister... the one who always there for you when you need someone to talk to. She's the listener who lives in the shadow of Jax, but deep inside she has sass and spice which made Cort love her more.

I think that one of the highlights for me while reading this book is when I realized that many of us can actually relate to Mad. There is always something inside of us, no matter what our exteriors show to everyone else, that is hidden and waiting to be free. I kinda envy Mad for having Cort--passionate and loving and who knows the real her, appreciate her and embrace her wholly. I fall for Cort as well, more and more throughout the story.

Marry Me Mad is like a second chance kind of book for me since Cort and Mad have loved each other since they were little but never had their chance until they meet after ten years or so. It is a story about two soulmates who are destined to love each other, but they needed time to grow separately and learn how to fight for true love and their happiness. It shows that some childhood feelings that is kept hidden through the years, when watered, sometimes makes the best kind of love. It can be a beautiful fairytale. Mad and Cort have that kind of fairytale.

Though I still love Jonquils for Jax better than Marry Me Mad, this book is all love. For a girl who is a sucker for Happily-Ever-After, Katy Regnery's books is always a go to. I think this is her forte. She always give beautiful endings. It's like a sweet escape from all the ugliness in life and it makes you believe that fairytales can still do happen.

Will I recommend this book? YES. Will I still read the next story? So freaking YES. Now, I am looking forward to J.C.'s story!

title: Parents of children with special needs - do not read
text:
Parents of children with special needs - do not read.
Overall, the book was very easy to read and I finished it quite quickly. The concept was interesting and I really enjoyed Finn's point of view.
But as a parent of a child with an intellectual disability, there were parts of the book that were almost too hard to read. But nothing compared to the dad admitting that he was relieved that his son had died. I can't imagine in a million years feeling that way.
The mother's complete lack of grief was troubling throughout the book.
I think it could have been a great book, if both children were grieved for in the ways that they deserved. And for Oz to not have been so marginalized, truly heartbreaking.

title: Bring a dictionary.
text: Bring a dictionary. This is a marvelously polysyllabic series of essays loosely bound together as a travelogue of Fermor’s sojourn in the Mani, a region of Greece that even Fermor describes as barren, hot and desolate. The sentences are often elaborately complex; the paragraphs discursive. One digression leads to another before circling back to the Mani. If you loved Fermor,s baroque vocabulary and incredible historical knowledge displayed in A Time of Gifts, you should love this. If you have never before read Fermor prepare yourself for beautiful prose, complicated genealogies and an extensive but erratic history of the Greek world. I recommend it with reservations.

It's not just war reporting but has all the little details which get left out normally, such as a description of an aircrew barracks or the fact that the women in an antiaircraft battery don't date the men from the same battery or the logistics of housing and feeding the men on a troopship.  I found it an absorbing read and highly recommend it.

title: A heart-racing action-packed adventure
text:
Misty Mills is going through an average day of work at her therapy office when she looks up and sees her ex Tanner, whom she hasn't seen in five years, standing in her doorway holding a baby. He tells her he's there on business with the FBI and needs her help finding out who the baby's mother is but three armed men come in to get the baby. Macy is pulled into the mystery and Tanner has been put in charge of keeping her and baby Addie safe until they can figure out what's going on. Why do people want the baby? How is Macy connected to the baby's family?

The action kicked up quickly and I was anxious to figure out how the bad guys were tracking Addie and how the mom knew Macy. I was engaged in the story and couldn't put the book down. I read it in about five hours. I also enjoyed learning the backstory between Macy and Tanner and seeing how they interacted in such close proximity while navigating their reintroduction into one another's lives. If you like action, suspense, mystery, and a little romance then you will thoroughly enjoy this book.

title: A nice introduction to the characters and series
text:
The Governess Gambit was an excellent start to the The Wild Wynchesters series that wonderfully sets up the characters and the events to come.

Chloe Wynchester and five other orphans were adopted as children by a wealthy baron with a noble purpose. Using his status in life, Baron Vanderbean works to right wrongs and fight for justice. Each of the Wynchesters has their own unique talents to aid in this quest. When the family learns of a unscrupulous headmistress exploiting orphans, the group put their skills to use to rescue the children.

Each of the Wynchesters is unique in their own way with skills that most would consider unusual. This novella, as well as the first full-length book, focuses on Chloe who has an uncanny ability to go unnoticed. Her ability to move about sight unseen allows her to infiltrate places forbidden to her. It's definitely a skill that comes in handy throughout this story. Chloe is a fascinating character and I'm looking forward to learning more about her in the next book. I really enjoyed the dynamic between the siblings, it's clear they all care for one another and they've developed a great routine for their work.

The primary focus of this novella is the Wynchesters working to discredit a school headmistress who is forcing orphans to work under the guise of giving them an education. I enjoyed watching the Wynchesters work and getting to see them show off their unique talents. The school storyline was quite interesting and I liked the way it wrapped up. A side plot in this novella is the theft of a painting belonging to the Wynchesters by a duke and the family's subsequent attempts to get the painting back from the man's son after he passes away. The painting storyline is unresolved in this novella as it is the primary focus of the first full-length book, The Duke Heist.

Overall I really enjoyed The Governess Gambit and I'm looking forward to reading The Duke Heist soon. I definitely recommend this novella to anyone planning to pick up the series.

title: an engaging, poignant read!
text:
I don't read a lot of "afterlife" books, generally, so this was a bit out of my comfort zone. But I'm so glad I made the jump (Har har. See what I did there?) because JUMP WHEN READY was an engaging, poignant book that stayed with me long after I read the last word.

Henry is a great character with a consistent, realistic teenage voice. At first I had a little trouble keeping his new friends straight, but soon enough their personalities emerged and I loved the interaction between them. The idea of a group of friends from different decades, with different experiences and frames of reference, is really cool, and worked well within the world David created.

The story of Henry's sister's abduction is intense and heart-wrenching. David kept me guessing as to how it would all play out, and I felt Henry's desperation and fear for Bethany right along with him. All of the characters in this book were really well developed, and that included the "bad guys" who kidnapped Bethany as well.

There are difficult topics addressed in this book - suicide, abduction, and the obvious - death - and I think all are handled with sensitivity and respect. Despite the serious themes, the story stays surprisingly upbeat, with an incredibly poignant ending that had me in tears (the good kind!). Seriously. The ending made this book for me. All the pieces were engaging and kept me reading, but the way David tied everything up made me want to go back to the beginning and read it all over again, just to appreciate how it all comes together. When I came to the end, I was happy to have had the experience of following Henry's story and touched by the time I spent in David's world.

I highly recommend this book, and hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

title: Some gems, but overall left me wanting
text:
I think I wanted to like this book more than I actually did. I enjoy the steampunk genre, but did not enjoy all of the stories in this anthology. All of the short stories are loosely tied together, that is, they take place in the same world of automatons. I found that I was not a huge fan of them when I was reading this book. My favorite selections were those by Chris Dolley (charming and funny), Pati Nagle (intriguing and interesting characters) and Katharine Kimbriel. The others I found merely average or forgettable. One thing that bothered me was the inconsistencies with terminology, grammar and spelling. However, that is rather easily overlooked. If you like automatons and steampunk, you will probably enjoy this compilation. However, if you dislike either, I suggest you look elsewhere.

This book was obtained freely through the LibraryThing Early Reviewers program in exchange for an honest review.

title: Another member of the club
text:
I think it was my mom who told me many years ago about how her co-workers were all now in the 'sandwich' generation, who were caring for their parents AND their children....

Well, fast forward probably 40 years, and I've been spending time caring for my parents, first my father now my mother, independent living, hiring caregivers, assisted living, selling houses, moving, falls, illnesses, etc. And now COVID preventing visiting...

Elizabeth Berg writes such a heart-wrenching but brutally honest account of her own experiences with her aging parents. I found myself nodding time and time again, I found myself feeling like I wasn't alone with this, with the feelings of guilt, with the discussions of what is the best thing to do, and that's all we can ever do, what seems like the best thing at the time. And, time is at once our friend and enemy. I noticed that there have been several years since the event described by Ms Berg and this book, I guess helping gain perspective.

All I can say now is read this book; if you don't need it yet, still read it to see what is to come.

Thank you to the publisher for lending me a time-constrained e-arc via Netgalley. This review is optional and my own opinion.

title: " Looks like some chapters dropped on the floor and were put ...
text:
Short, choppy sentences detract from flow of reading.Example: "The snow swirled. I smelled fur. Tasted blood in the air." and..."I hiked across the frozen tundra. I was exhaused. My eyelids feld heavy. My muscles ached." and..."I graabbed it. He pulled. My arms slid through the door. My body lifted off the ground. The building quaked. It dropped an inch into the ice.." and..."My toes stung. My Fingers hurt. My ears felt cold." and..."The wind picked up speed. My cheeks throbbed. My core temperature sasnk even further. I wiggled my fingers. They barely moved."

Looks like some chapters dropped on the floor and were put back without regard to chronological placement. Flashbacks are okay, to some degree, in a novel, but there still needs to be some segue or date or something to let the reader know that it is a flashback, and to how far back. There's nothing wrong with the plot, but there are some questionable issues of plausibility. (A woman lets out a blood-curdling scream, filling a guy's ears, while being smothered by a pillow by a guy holding it down with both hands.Then she screams again, with a voice that sounded weak and lifeless.

I quit this book after completing two thirds of it, but couldn't take any more.

title: Mystery and Murder in Regency England
text: I must confess that I enjoy historical mysteries immensely.  This first book in the Sebatien St. Cyr series, takes place in one of my favorite eras, Regency England, the time and place Jane Austen wrote about so well.  However, this book takes place,in the dark and foggy and filthy underbelly of London that Austen never knew. Sebastian St. Cyr , Vicount Devlin, is a fascinating but saturnine hero.  Why is he at odds with his father, the Earl of Hendon?  What mystery lies in his past, especially when he was away in the army's Peninsula Campaigns?  The horrific murder of a high class prostitute seems to implicate Sebastian.  There is also the complication of a French spy ring , a long lost love, and the appealing side kick in the person of a pickpocket urchin.  Throw in a host of possible suspects and the very atmospheric background of the city of London itself and you have a fast paced, absorbing mystery to enjoy.

title: My Review
text:
DCI Kate Daniels, her partner Hank Gormley, with the rest of the MIT are tracking a killer. Kate is also still trying to solve an unsolved from the prior year. As it turns out, the cases may be related.

Vibrant details fill the pages for character, scenery, and narrative descriptions allowing rich and thorough enjoyment throughout the tale.

As the narrative progresses, we learn as the characters learn about the twisting mysteries, as well as, the personal obstacles the characters face and overcome. The story line is primarily told from the perspective of Kate Daniels, yet does seamlessly shift to other perspectives as needed.

Both the action and the mystery components of the story are well plotted and consistent throughout.

Overall, a thrilling read!

text:
Book 2 in the Power Chain series, we have Paxton and Laurel. They've known each other for years and have a history, but it's not all roses. When Pax decides he's taking Laurel back, he does it in one of the most infuriating ways I've ever read about! I seriously wanted to smack him upside the head for that. And I'm positive Laurel did too. The characters are strong and well-defined, and each have their place in the Power Chain group. Pax's actions aren't ideal, but if you break it down, there's chivalry behind them. Twisted chivalry, but still there!
Although it's a standalone, naturally you'll get the most out of it by reading book 1 first, and even 0.5 (which i still haven't caught up on!). The basics of their business are explained, but again, you get more out of that by starting at the beginning.
I love Ellen Sue, their 'mother hen' who keeps them... no in line, but she tends to their houses and such when they need her. I love that she's a constant through these books, and always sides with 'her boys' and isn't a pushover to the women who try to wheedle information out of her! She's such a great character

title: Oh my stars!!
text:
Independent Reviewer for Archaeolibrarian - I Dig Good Books!

I love, love, love the “ahha” moment in a story when the title makes sense. The ahha moment in this book is so,so, so good but so sad at the same time. It’s a mixed bowl of emotions and I would honestly expect nothing less from our sweet, sweet India!

If you’ve read any other book by India, you’ll know she doesn’t stick to just one genre of books. She has branched out to a few different genre’s and I think she has written them all equally well. What I really absolutely enjoy is that I have been reading her books nearly back to back and have yet to get sick of her writing style or the stories that she writes. I’ve gone through phases where I would read one author’s books back to back and by the third to fourth book in I was struggling and finding it hard to make myself read the story. I’ve not experienced this yet with India’s writing and this book makes the fourth book of hers that I’ve read. I think this says a lot about her writing style and the ability to write in a couple of different genres. The story lines are different but the detail is also vastly different from one another. It’s kind of like taking a deep breath and starting a new project.

This story is intense. It’s deep, it’s emotional, it’s pretty heavy. It’s full of detail, descriptions, and emotions. There is a lot going on at times so I feel that concentration into the story is a must, or you might get off track. There are a lot of characters to keep track of and those characters are mentioned quite often so it’s important to keep track of them all.

It’s very apparent that this story, book 1, is simply setting the stage for future books. It maps out the scenery, introduces the cast, both good and evil, and introduces us to a truly interesting story. It kind of feels like it could be a fairytale of sorts. It ends semi-abruptly and personally, I might have a little frustration towards the author for the way that she ended it. That’s simply because I wanted more. I needed more. I was hooked and I’m just kind of hanging. Now, had she continued writing the story so it could be all in one book, it would be a massive book. I appreciate where she left off but I’m silently begging for the next book.

One last thing that I feel needs mentioning was the way she wrote one particular part of the story. It was referencing the Elves’ and their ability to help one another, without expecting more, without frustration, and with joy. They didn’t need to ask for help, their fellow friends were there, with their hands out, willing to help. It was automatic and without disdain. It was so opposite of what we experience today. It caused me to pause, think of my actions, my friends’ actions, my co-worker’s actions. It made me think of how I am raising my children. It simply just made me pause and think. It was such an important message that I hope others were able to grasp its importance as much as I did.

I’d absolutely recommend this story. I feel like I’m leaving out some other major details that made this story just absolutely knock my socks off, but I hope I gave you enough information to make you want to go read this book, now. It was such a good read, I can’t wait for book two.

* A copy of this book was provided to me with no requirements for a review. I voluntarily read this book, and my comments here are my honest opinion. *
