title: Powerful
text:
The story of Lincoln's last days is told in the first person by the physician who ministered to the president at his death.  Dr. Leale was a commissioned officer in the Medical Dept. of the Army, in charge of the Wounded Commissioned Officers' Ward in Washington, DC.  He was an eye-witness to the shooting and was the first person admitted to the President's Box after the shooting.

The doctor offers an almost minute-by-minute report on what happened as Lincoln inched closer to death.  He was sure that Lincoln's sight was gone, because of the angle of the bullet, but he was sure that Lincoln could hear and so he made sure Lincoln heard when he called for his son, Robert, talked with Mrs. Lincoln, his pastor's prayers, etc.  Because Dr. Leale was aware that the dying can have better sensory or hearing acuity near death, he made sure that he always was holding Lincoln's hand firmly.  In the end, Leale's efforts extended Lincoln's life for nine hours.

This story is so simple and modestly told that it delivers a recitation of great power.  This is a wonderful, original source, of an important moment in American history.

title: A story as sweet as maple syrup!
text:
Noah trying to not fall for Amelia is pointless.. but he is determined because he's been burned by love before. He will play the grumpy man role as much as possible to keep her from getting close. She's not going to be more than the woman who's car broke down in his yard. He'll be happy when she's gone back to her celebrity life.. because he needs to be.

Amelia knows she has no business falling for Noah. She's only here in his town for a chance to breath from stardom. (And because Audrey Hepburn inspired her.) As soon as her car is fixed she'll leave. She'll get out of his hair. Despite the obvious sparks Noah's made it clear he does not want anything romantic with her. But, darn it, he's exactly what she needs and wants. Someone who treats her like a regular person, doesn't expect her to play a part, and isn't after her wealth. As a pop princess is been years since someone's seen her as.. her. To make matters worse she's finding under all the surliness he's deeply caring and as sweet as maple syrup.

Sarah Adams has such a gift with storytelling. She hooks you quick and keeps you that way through the whole book. She blends humor, passion, growth, and coziness into every book she writes. Many people have said a Sarah Adams book feels like a hug and I'd have to agree! 🥰

title: THE Ultimate Guide to Self-Sustenance
text:
Nicholas Hyde's Recipe for Survival is truly a must-read for any North American or those living in temperate climates who wants to be prepared for the distinct but hopefully remote eventuality that the world as we know it would suddenly collapse. At the very least, guide suggests very practical pointers on how to save money, be more self-sufficient, and live a healthier life (as a result of healthier fresh and organic food sources and a good old hard work) all in one in a way that everyone would understand.

It's chock full of information on the various how-tos of food production, some of which appear surprising to me. For example, I didn't realize how easy it was to make goat cheese out of goat milk, that you actually used faux eggs to identify a potential mother/nesting hen, or that rabbits could actually be milked(!), which the author did not recommend by the way.

What you get is a 150-page guide to
- the best types of crops (fruits, vegetables, tubers, and grains) to plant during specific seasons of the year with some valuable tips on how to optimize your yield, how to compost,
- sensible recommendations of domestic livestock that are both cost-effective and relatively easy to raise
- how to make your own salt, sugar/sweetener (!), and cooking oil
- tips on fishing, trapping, hunting, and foraging for food sources.
- how to make your own flour, bread, and pasta
- step by step instructions on how to can, store, and preserve your surplus food
- how to make your own vinegar, wine, beer, and other libations
- 10 delicious-sounding off-the-grid dinner recipes

What could have made it better
- For all it's detailed simplicity, some of the chapters could have been made more reader-friendly and scannable by making use of bulleted or numbered guides, as well as breaking down larger chunks of information under different uniform subheadings.
- For the descriptions of each crop, specific nutritional content, not necessarily in terms of caloric breakdown, could have been added instead of generically stating that this or that were nutritious.
- Pictures and illustrations/diagrams could have made it easier to understand some of the tips and techniques he was introducing
- A glossary of terms, particularly of the more technical ones would be very helpful to the reader

title: Wasn't for me
text: This author displays a talent for creative writing skills, but the plot was lacking in creativity.  I disagree with all of the other reviews of this book.  The characters lacked depth.  The main character is a criminal lawyer,but there were so many glaring inconsistencies regarding legal protocol and procedures that it was obvious the author did not do much research.  It would be like me writing a travel guide for ("the authors beloved") Wyoming even though I've only visited the state once.  The use of a thesaurus would have been helpful, i.e., "Bitch" is not the only word available to describe a female you don't care for, even when trying to sound like a thug for organized crime.  If you're looking for a book that has great sex scenes (the reason I gave 2 stars instead of 1), but don't care about the pages between the sex scenes, then this book is for you.  If you're looking for romance and depth, don't bother with this book.  If you have any back ground in criminal law or law enforcement and want a book to be believable and accurate, don't buy this book.

title: OVERTURE
text:
4.5/5 Rating

The story line wasn't your average forbidden romance. The quality was in depth but had a rich slow burn. The characters didn't exude some type of insta lust and/or insta love. The characters were complex because their past played into how they would interact in the present. At first, I wasn't quite sure if I would like Samantha. I didn't want the character to play the role as a brat. I didn't want them to be immature while seeking the attention of an older gentleman. Thankfully, Samantha wasn't like that at all. She was such an old soul. She had to grow quickly and wasn't sure who to trust. I felt like Samantha wanted to place that trust in the hands of her guardian. But she was so scared... Samantha was scared of being abandoned. I feel like all of us has felt abandoned a time or two. Maybe alone...

Liam... I loved his character from the get go. He was man of precision and control. He barely let down his guard. I felt like he wanted to for Samantha but he didn't know how to it. Liam was all about protecting Samantha from dangerous places and/or people. He wanted her from himself, which made me so sad. I want to make the reader aware, if they didn't already know, this isn't a standalone. Overture is just the being of Liam and Samantha's story. The part happens in Concerto. Don't know when it will be released but I'm looking forward to it.

title: A Great Self-Discovery Journey!
text:
I was immediately pulled into the story as the author allowed Anna to express her feeling of loss and the strain in her marriage. Told in the perspective of Anna, the reader has a sense of loss toward the beginning and is easily able to embark on a journey of self love and discovery with this character.

The assortment of characters are a great addition to this read. Especially, sweet eight-year-old Lucita and kind Clark. With the help of these two, Anna learns things about herself that she didn’t previously know and throws herself back into writing to help her healing process.

When Anna journeyed to South Carolina, I did find this pacing a bit slow at times. Describing some of the minimal tasks didn’t seem too necessary. Toward the end, though, my heart was racing and I did find the situations realistic. The only other issue I took was Anna’s family resistance of her change was a bit too dramatic; Anna is a grown woman who has a career and a life, so I didn’t understand why her family was trying to guilt her in returning. It was clear that the path Anna was on wasn’t working for her and she needed something new.

Overall, the book was well-written and a pleasure to read.

title: The primer for understanding the Middle East.
text:
I saw you on Mr. Maher's show and was very impressed by your thorough knowledge of the Middle East. I also remembered you on NBC evening news news with Brian Williams when you were on Tahrir Square in Cairo. So, I bought your latest book. Once I started reading it I could not put it down. Your total grasp of the Middle East is astounding. You are so right -- you cannot export democracy, or plant it as a flower. I agree with you fully that a number of Big Men will again dominate the middle East just like before we, the USA, entered Iraq. Then things really fell apart!
I wish you all the best, and enjoy your family.

title: One of my top fave of the year!
text:
Omg! I went into Requiem blind and I totally don't regret it. Callie Hart has blown me away with this one!

"Life has a weird way of giving us what we need, not what we want." -Theo

Sorrell blames Theo for her best friend Rachel's death for the night that changed all their lives forever. She wants revenge but when she sees Theo again, she has to fight past the attraction and those deep feelings that are longing for Theo.
Callie Hart has created such beautiful characters, strong, independent and devoted. I knew there was more to Theo that met the eye and when twists are revealed, I found myself on the edge of my seat. I love the way this author creates angst and gives such descriptive details because this story made my emotions go through a mini rollercoaster. I don't want to give much away because the story is not at all what you expect but it is truly beautifully written and one of the best enemies to lovers story I've read this year! Round of applause for Callie Hart because she's done it again! 👏👏👏

title: Ok read
text:
This was an okay read, but not one that stood out in any way from a hundred others except that the two cowboy Doms in the title are a bit more of jerks than some and the premise is more than a bit shaky.

Molly Miller and her sister are looking for a job at the BDSM Club at Pleasure Ranch, not knowing its closed for repair. Derrick Houston, immediately attracted to Molly, hires them as ranch hands for the ranch he and his brother Caleb run. This is where the premise becomes weird. No one who relies on a ranch as their financial support is going to hire two ranch hands who have never been on a ranch, don't know how to ride horses, and one of whom is terrified of chickens.

In spite of her inexperience, Molly gives the work her best shot. Caleb shares Derrick's attraction to her, but is more hesitant about her willingness to live on the ranch. After both brothers share some sexual moments with Molly, they decide to "test" her by not completing the sexual act. Molly is insecure about her place with the brothers, and is ready to leave before they finally wake up and realize they are about to lose her. At least they then apologize and tell her how much she means to them.

I found Derrick weak and Caleb infuriating. Molly was strong, but should have been strong enough to dump the brothers and find somewhere else to work as soon as they played the "test" card.

Basically, this was an ok book although the author shows some promise for future tales.

Review copy provided for an honest review.

title: Mixed feelings. (contains spoilers)
text:
My overall impression is to give a good 4 or 5 stars because I found the plot very engaging. Whether certain scenarios were predictable or not I found myself wondering what would happen next because it was written differently enough from canon to be intriguing. And there was no great emphasis on peripheral characters. There were no long tangents rhapsodizing on Jane and Bingley's wretched plight or on Caroline's or Collins' machinations. It was all ODC for the most part (even when Wickham and Georgiana were discussed).

However, there is one MAJOR fly in the ointment: the book is simply over-narrated. There is so much repetitive, long-winded explanation of events and introspection by Darcy and Elizabeth that they barely speak to each other. Their dialogue alone I would wager comprises 15% of the book or less. The amount of times that the two "open their mouths to speak" then fail to do so is utterly maddening. This left very little opportunity to develop any kind of fulfilling understanding. I rolled with it for about half the book, then I started to get irritated because I knew where it was inevitably headed. Small matters and details were drawn out and expounded upon in repetitive fashion, and, alas, the most important matter, the crux of the plot was hurriedly laid out in one or two pages at the VERY end then BOOM--epilogue.

After reading the final chapters I felt like deducting several stars based on the conclusion alone. The consummation of the marriage is built up as the major plot point throughout but inexplicably we are left to completely imagine it in the end. And when it comes to the hard fought for declaration of feelings we find that on one side they have been overheard rather than conveyed directly. They're almost stated as a foregone conclusion rather than a shocking revelation. That makes little sense given how devoted both were to the idea that the other could never love them. Very disappointing culmination of what was a decent read.

title: Second in series of Queen Elizabeth solving murders.

Rosie is an interesting character, but the personality of the Queen was better in the first book.  There were too many secondary characters,to provide red herrings I guess.  When a murder occurs at Buckingham Palace, the Queen gets involved with solving the case.  This one is just okay.

title: 5 BEAUTIFUL LANDON STARS
text:
BOOK REVIEW by Michelle 20th MAY 2013:

RATING: 5 BEAUTIFUL LANDON STARS

After falling for Oscar Maree in Hale Maree, I wondered how Misty was going to write Landon. Oscar is a beautiful , phwoaaaarrr!! smexi lad whose persistence won Hale over, not to mention his...........

Misty wrote a most gorgeous voice in Landon. The lad is this mix of humour, thinks outside the box, not afraid to accept responsibility.... and can he make your toes curl.

I uber uber uber loved this book!

I laughed so much. Misty has this magnificent witty talent. I connected with Landon in Hale Maree, I knew I wanted to read his book and I knew I wanted him to hook up with Sher.

Sher is this loveable, total giggle pot. She has a most unique voice for a character. I loved hearing Landon's inner monologue about Sher and her giggling.

I loved her giggling.

I could hear her giggles.... especially the chainsaw ones.

LOL!

"We're going hobbit hunting," Sher giggles, but it doesn't derail Saul in the least.

How've you been?" I inquire lightly annnd...she giggles. Damn. It's like a bucket of ice in my shorts.

I just came off of a quickie relationship with Amy-the-Psychopath, and now I've landed the Giggler, who might actually end up going Jack the Ripper on me.

A serious topic is the basis for Misty's story about Landon and Sher and she handles it brilliantly.

I have not laughed so much one minute and then had my toes curl the next in a book.

I tug her earlobe into my mouth, or maybe it's her lip... I don't have a clue. It's just soft and warm and makes me think of nipples.

"That's fine," I tell her. "But if you happen to be the one that gets thirsty first, I just want you to know, I'm not stingy with my milk at all."

She reaches across me, brushing over my crotch, and the alarm in my jean-submarine instantly flashes: Semen! All hands on deck!

OMG!

I have some favourite scenes.

*waggles eyebrows *

Misty put the sizzle in Landon and Sher.

Misty really does have writing talent. She drew me in from the first page. I connected with Landon, and his inner monologue is brilliant fun and how he sees Sher and how he wants to give her what she thinks she will miss. He really is a stand up guy. He is honest with himself and with Sher with regards to the situation and that is all you can do.

I really love a guy like Landon. There is just something special about the way they see life and what it throws at them and how they handle it. He has such a talent for being creative in his endeavors to try to stop Sher making a big mistake in his eyes.

I loved how much he cares.

Give Sher a reason, give her a life. The things she wants to do though - horse riding, pole dancing, tattoos, sex with strangers - I'm not sure how okay I am with letting her have four whole episodes of `Sherr Gone Wild'. I'm sure as hell not going out to recruit a dude to do her on the beach.

A very clever story that even had me getting a bit teary.

Landon knows how to bring romance to the picnic ... his style of picnic. To have a guy in your life like Landon who truly puts the thinking cap on to make a girl feel special is something to see.

"You can stop trying to be my hero," she says. "I don't need one."

"But I do," I tell her, "and this was the address they gave me."

Horses, pole dancing, tattoos, stranger sex on the beach. I try to keep my lip from hanging open.

"Okay," I rub my hands together slowly. "I really didn't see three of those things coming."

The sub characters are very entertaining. I loved Sher's interesting family. Her mother Lisa, is quite a character that you can't help but like and her oompa loompa sized brothers and sisters are like rugrats on Red Bull.

Sher showed her ability to be a great mother and role model when the rugrats joined in the story.

I loved having Oscar pop up with Hale. They are such great characters and I just loved hearing Oscar's voice again.

I can see why Oscar and Landon are such good friends. They both won't let the girl in their life run away without a fight. They love hard.
I totally dig that you don't have to read Hale Maree first to read Landon and Sher's story, but I highly recommend that you read Hale Maree first , so you can meet Oscar and get your glimpse of Landon. He will make you want to read more.

This was a story that the doctor ordered. I needed a book to have something different in a contemporary.

This is a funny, witty, heart warming read with some theft and major giggle fits. Landon will show you why he can fall for a chainsaw giggler and you will be rooting for him to win Sher over.
Misty delivers in true Misty style.

Michelle

title: Strong psychological thriller
text:
A dead woman is brought onto the beach by the sea and found by a little girl and her mother.
Miles from there, happily married Carmen and Tom live in the city. What is the link?

No need to grill me, I admit this book is a cover choice. That blue is mesmerizing. Now that I think of it, I could have picked it for Halloween, and not just because of the cover. If some of us find happiness in magic worlds or intergalactic wars, I get all the feelings from psychological thrillers. I ain’t scared of monsters! Except when they look and sound like your husband.

Carmen is finally happy. She almost has it all. A nice apartment in London, a handsome and caring husband, and step kids to take care of on weekends. Yes, she was made redundant because of the economic crisis but free time is a good thing, right? Well, it depends on what you do with all those hours.

The perfect blended family and couple bliss image take a hit when a remark by a strange about a murder makes Carmen think about her husband Tom’s past. It all happens quite early in the book, and from that moment on, I could not put it down. Tom had confessed it all to Carmen a long time ago. How his marriage had ended, how he had met Her, younger, beautiful, how he used to take her to St Jude’s just like they did now with the kids, how she had gone missing and been found later, dead on the beach. But knowing about it does not mean you are not curious.

For once, there is no big secret hovering over heads and fears of a happy bubble exploding. Many elements are in the open air, known to the main character, and when I thought it would only take the thrill away, I was proven wrong. How so wrong! Knowing a truth does not mean you know the whole truth, and this is what the book is about. How much do you say to make people believe you? How much do you keep hidden, stored away in a box? And why is the entire story better left unsaid? These are the questions I kept asking myself while devouring chapter after chapter. I was growing more curious with every page while Carmen was getting more puzzled with every hour.

One remark, it is all it takes to create a doubt. Suddenly words turn into doubts, and your mind won’t snap out of it. A word, a look, a question unanswered, and a woman’s mind goes wild. One thing leading to another and before you realize it you are making every possible scenario in your head. From there goes the snowball effect. I am not saying we all are crazy paranoid beings ready to jump on our better halves at the first sign of something sketchy (says the girl who made a scene about a lipstick stain on a towel before noticing she was wearing the same shade of lipstick on her lips that same day… :p) But the right circumstances and a series of details can lead to something so much bigger than you could ever imagine.
The shady husband trope is my thing. Husbands make for the perfect suspect, and Tom is a brilliant lawyer, a loving father, and a wonderful character to doubt.

I love that Carmen’s suspicions are all based on substantial details, leaving the reader questioning her mindset and sanity. Is it okay to erase something from a computer? I do it every day, does that make me a killer? Is forgetting to mention something a lie? I warmed to Carmen very early on, when her life was all about what to eat and how to keep the kids busy, and it was very interesting to see the impact of the events on her decisions and actions. Every character is portrayed in a way that makes them real, sometimes relatable, sometimes despicable, but always real. Tom and the children are no simple secondary characters, and the family ties are strongly represented, giving the story a heavier tone. After all, all families are complicated!

So many questions came in waves as I was scrabbling to reach the end. I doubted everything, and even though I managed to get a couple of answers before the end, the steady pace kept me on my toes and the race of the last pages left me breathless.

Undertow is a strong psychological thriller using our deepest fears and playing with the —sometimes blind — trust we put in others. It will make you think twice about what you think you know and keep you turning pages long after curfew!

I received an advanced copy of this book.

title: Attention grabbing!
text:
In the interests of instilling a love of reading in our children we read to them. A lot! What is crucial is that the books we read grab their attention and keep them riveted.

And if it can keep the parents who have to read it entertained as well its a welcome bonus. And finally, if there is a lesson or two in there, subtle enough not be be seen as lessons, then great!

The whole family enjoyed this book. My wife and I read some each night with the kids always begging for more, no matter how much we read. We had to learn to stop early, then agree to 'one more chapter'. The adults enjoyed the book as much as the kids because it took us back to what it felt like to be young, and the challenges and issues we faced.

I got the distinct impression the author has not grown up himself, which is just what's needed in a children's book author. Justin captured what it was like to be a kid as if he was still living it.

title: Great work by teachers reimagining success in the classroom.
text: “Going Gradeless” is a masterful treatise on reinventing teaching and learning. It leads readers from a one-and-done mindset (e.g. take a test once and forget what you learned) to “failing gloriously” and trying again until mastery (i.e. learning by rethinking, rewriting, re-calculating, etc.). Unlike many books that talk theory,  Elise Burns and David Frangiosa share data from their classroom, explain their methods, explore their setbacks, and describe the ways in which they improved—and continue to. Any teacher would do well to pick up a copy of this book. It will help jumpstart the journey that leads to mastery for both students and teachers.

It is a sobering, heartbreaking reminder of the cruelty of men and of governments. Masai Ishikawa’s story will haunt me for a long time to come.

I normally do not enjoy translated books, but this was simple and easy to read. Some may say it was too simplistic, but it helped make the deep topics more consumable. I wish Masai Ishikawa peace in the rest of his life.

title: Learn What Not To Do
text: Today, with the prevalence of social media coloring the "news" landscape, it's extremely important to be aware of what you say, how you say it, and the consequences of shooting from the lip. title: 2.5 Stars- ‘Ok’ Short Story
text:
My goal for this year was to read more new/Indie horror authors, so started out with the loudest touted in a FB group and RJ is definitely one of those.

Pros:
Great premise, the story has a lot of potential

Last 20 or so pages flowed much better than the front third of the story

Cons:

Needs editing, although I normally don’t worry too much about that for Indie authors, I still mention it.

It drives me insane to read Stephen King references in stories. Yes, we get it, you like King, but did you have to throw not one, but several scenes in there? Its forced and definitely served no purpose in one instance and the main occurrence literally made me roll my eyes. This seems to be a trend lately in the Indie world and the practice can’t die soon enough.

Men should never write about menstruation . Seriously, like never, ever. I don’t like that scene on Carrie because that would have NEVER happened yet now all male writers seem to think that’s how it goes.

Several parts of the story were... inconceivable. Like, grossly so. I don’t want to spoil the story, but there was no way it happened the way it happened. 😉😂

I think with time and honest feedback, this author has potential.
